title: From Punjab Istri Sabha
excerpt: "ਔਰਤ ਦੇ ਸਨਮਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਮੈਦਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ" ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਨੇ ਨੈਸ਼ਨਲ ਫੈਡਰੇਸ਼ਨ ਆਫ ਇੰਡੀਅਨ ਵੋਮੈਨ ਦੇ ਸੱਦੇ ਤੇ 30 ਜਨਵਰੀ ਨੂੰ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਵਿੱਚ "ਔਰਤ ਦੇ ਸਨਮਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਮੈਦਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ" ਮੁਹਿੰਮ ਦੀ ਸ਼ੁਰੂਆਤ ਕੀ
content: "ਔਰਤ ਦੇ ਸਨਮਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਮੈਦਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ" ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਨੇ ਨੈਸ਼ਨਲ ਫੈਡਰੇਸ਼ਨ ਆਫ ਇੰਡੀਅਨ ਵੋਮੈਨ ਦੇ ਸੱਦੇ ਤੇ 30 ਜਨਵਰੀ ਨੂੰ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਵਿੱਚ "ਔਰਤ ਦੇ ਸਨਮਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਮੈਦਾਨ ਵਿੱਚ" ਮੁਹਿੰਮ ਦੀ ਸ਼ੁਰੂਆਤ ਕੀਤੀ ਵਰਨਣ ਯੋਗ ਹੈ ਕਿ ਇਸ ਵੇਲੇ ਔਰਤ ਜਾਤੀ ਨੂੰ ਗੰਭੀਰ ਚੁਨੌਤੀਆਂ ਦਾ ਸਾਹਮਣਾ ਕਰਨਾ ਪੈ ਰਿਹਾ ਹੈ ਔਰਤਾਂ ਦੀ ਛੇੜਛਾੜ, ਬਲਾਤਕਾਰ ਅਤੇ ਕਤਲ ਆਮ ਹੋ ਗਏ ਹਨ। ਵਿਚ ਬਹੁਤ ਔਰਤਾਂ ਦਾ ਬਲਾਤਕਾਰ ਹੋਇਆ ਅਤੇ ਕਈ ਕਤਲ ਵੀ ਹੋ ਗਈਆਂ।ਬੀ .ਜੇ .ਪੀ ਸ਼ਾਸਤ ਰਾਜਾਂ ਵਿੱਚ ਇਹ ਵਰਤਾਰਾ ਆਮ ਹੈ।ਹਾਕਮ ਧਿਰ ਪੀੜਤਾਂ ਦੀ ਮਦਦ ਕਰਨ ਦੀ ਬਜਾਏ ਜਾਲਮ ਅਤੇ ਗੁੰਡਾ ਕਿਸਮ ਦੇ ਲੋਕਾਂ ਦੀ ਪਿੱਠ ਤੇ ਖੜੀ ਹੁੰਦੀ ਹੈ। ਜਿਸ ਤੋਂ ਸਮਝ ਲੱਗਦੀ ਹੈ ਕਿ ਇਸ ਕਿਸਮ ਦੇ ਗੁੰਡਿਆਂ ਨੂੰ ਸਰਕਾਰੀ ਪੁਸ਼ਤ ਪਨਾਹੀ ਹਾਸਲ ਹੈ ਬਿਲਕੀਸ ਬਾਨੋ ਕੇਸ ਵਿੱਚ ਦੋਸ਼ੀਆਂ ਨੂੰ ਛੱਡ ਦੇਣਾ ਅਤੇ ਜੇਲ ਤੋਂ ਬਾਹਰ ਆਉਣ ਤੇ ਉਹਨਾਂ ਦਾ ਸ਼ਾਨਦਾਰ ਸਵਾਗਤ ਕਰਨਾ ਗੁੰਡਾਗਰਦੀ ਨੂੰ ਸ਼ਹਿ ਦਿੰਦਾ ਹੈ। ਔਰਤ ਦੀ ਹੋ ਰਹੀ ਬੇਕਦਰੀ ਨੂੰ ਵੇਖ ਕੇ ਨੈਸ਼ਨਲ ਫੈਡਰੇਸ਼ਨ ਆਫ ਇੰਡੀਅਨ ਵੋਮੈਨ ਨੇ ਫੈਸਲਾ ਕੀਤਾ ਹੈ ਕਿ ਸਾਰੇ ਦੇਸ਼ ਵਿੱਚ 30 ਜਨਵਰੀ ਤੋਂ ਲੈ ਕੇ 15 ਫਰਵਰੀ ਤੱਕ ਵੱਖ-ਵੱਖ ਢੰਗਾਂ ਨਾਲ ਇਸ ਵਿਸ਼ੇ ਤੇ ਐਕਸ਼ਨ ਕੀਤੇ ਜਾਣਗੇ ਇਸ ਦੇ ਨਾਲ ਨਾਲ ਆਪਣੇ ਲੋਕਲ ਮੁੱਦੇ ਵੀ ਜੋੜ ਲਏ ਜਾਣਗੇ। ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਨੇ ਇਸ ਮੁਹਿੰਮ ਦੀ ਸ਼ੁਰੂਆਤ 30 ਜਨਵਰੀ ਨੂੰ ਦੋ ਜਿਲਿਆਂ ਵਿੱਚ ਵੱਡੇ ਪ੍ਰੋਗਰਾਮ ਕਰਵਾ ਕੇ ਕੀਤੀ ਫਰੀਦ ਕੋਟ ਵਿੱਚ ਜਿਲਾ ਪ੍ਰਧਾਨ ਮਨਜੀਤ ਕੌਰ ਨੇ ਆਪਣੀਆਂ ਸਾਥਣਾਂ ਨਾਲ ਰਲ ਕੇ ਇੱਕ ਵੱਡਾ ਇਕੱਠ ਕੀਤਾ ਜਿਸ ਨੂੰ ਸੰਬੋਧਨ ਕਰਨ ਵਾਸਤੇ ਨਰਿੰਦਰ ਸੋਹਲ ਸੂਬਾ ਜਨਰਲ ਸਕੱਤਰ ਪਹੁੰਚੇ। ਇਸ ਤੋਂ ਇਲਾਵਾ ਸੀਪੀਆਈ ਆਗੂ ਅਸ਼ੋਕ ਕੁਮਾਰ ਕੌਸ਼ਲ ਜੀ ਨੇ ਵੀ ਸੰਬੋਧਨ ਕੀਤਾ। ਨਰੇਗਾ ਵਰਕਰ ਇਸ ਰੈਲੀ ਵਿੱਚ ਵੱਡੀ ਗਿਣਤੀ ਵਿੱਚ ਪਹੁੰਚੇ ।ਇਸੇ ਕਰਕੇ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਨੇ ਨਰੇਗਾ ਵਰਕਰ ਵਾਸਤੇ 700 ਰੁਪਏ ਦਿਹਾੜੀ ਅਤੇ 200 ਦਿਨ ਕੰਮ ਦੀ ਮੰਗ ਦੀ ਹਮਾਇਤ ਕੀਤੀ। ਤਰਨ ਤਾਰਨ ਜਿਲੇ ਦੀ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਨੇ 30 ਜਨਵਰੀ ਨੂੰ ਵਲਟੋਹਾ ਬੁਲਾਕ ਵਿੱਚ ਇੱਕ ਸ਼ਾਨਦਾਰ ਪ੍ਰੋਗਰਾਮ ਕੀਤਾ, ਜਿਸ ਦੀ ਤਿਆਰੀ ਸੂਬਾ ਵਿੱਤ ਸਕੱਤਰ ਕਿਰਨਬੀਰ ਵਲਟੋਹਾ ਨੇ ਕੀਤੀ। ਸੂਬਾ ਪ੍ਰਧਾਨ ਰਜਿੰਦਰ ਪਾਲ ਕੌ,ਰ ਜਿਲਾ ਪ੍ਰਧਾਨ ਸੀਮਾ ਸੋਹਲ ,ਜਿਲਾ ਜਨਰਲ ਸਕੱਤਰ ਰੂਪਿੰਦਰ ਮਾੜੀ ਮੇਘਾ ਅਤੇ ਸੂਬਾ ਸਰਪਰਸਤ ਨਰਿੰਦਰ ਪਾਲ ਪਾਲੀ ਸਮੇਤ ਇਕ ਵੱਡਾ ਕਾਫਲਾ ਗੱਡੀਆਂ ਦਾ ਲੈ ਕੇ ਜਿੰਨਾ ਉੱਤੇ ਆਪਣੀਆਂ ਮੰਗਾਂ ਸਬੰਧੀ ਪੋਸਟਰ ਲਗਾਏ ਹੋਏ ਸਨ ਅਤੇ ਸਪੀਕਰ ਰਾਹੀਂ ਸੰਦੇਸ਼ ਦਿੰਦਾ ਹੋਇਆ ਵੱਖ ਵੱਖ ਬਲਾਕਾਂ ਚੋਂ ਲੰਘ ਕੇ ਵਲਟੋਹਾ ਵਿਖੇ ਪਹੁੰਚਿਆ। ਜਿੱਥੇ ਇਹਨਾਂ ਸਾਰੇ ਆਗੂਆਂ ਨੇ ਸੰਬੋਧਨ ਕਰਕੇ ਸਰਕਾਰ ਦੀਆਂ ਨਾਕਾਮੀਆਂ ਦਾ ਅਤੇ ਆਪਣੀਆਂ ਮੰਗਾਂ ਦਾ ਵਰਨਣ ਕੀਤਾ ਪੰਜਾਬ ਇਸਤਰੀ ਸਭਾ ਨੇ ਰੁਜ਼ਗਾਰ, ਮੁਫਤ ਅਤੇ ਲਾਜ਼ਮੀ ਸਿੱਖਿਆ ਸਿਹਤ ਸਹੂਲਤਾਂ ਆਦਿ ਨੂੰ ਵੀ ਆਪਣੀਆਂ ਮੰਗਾਂ ਵਿੱਚ ਸ਼ਾਮਿਲ ਕੀਤਾ ਇਸ ਤੋਂ ਇਲਾਵਾ ਫਿਰਕਾ ਪ੍ਰਸਤ ਤਾਕਤਾਂ ਤੋਂ ਲੋਕਾਂ ਨੂੰ ਜਾਗਰੂਕ ਕੀਤਾ ਇਹ ਮੁਹਿੰਮ 15 ਫਰਵਰੀ ਤੱਕ ਜਾਰੀ ਰੱਖੀ ਜਾਏਗੀ ਅਤੇ ਵੱਖ-ਵੱਖ ਜਿਲਿਆਂ ਵਿੱਚ ਰੈਲੀਆਂ ਕਰਵਾ ਕੇ ਲੋਕਾਂ ਤੱਕ ਪਹੁੰਚ ਕੀਤੀ ਜਾਵੇਗੀ।ਰਜਿੰਦਰ content: हमारी बिहार की साथी निवेदिता जी ने उन् फिलिस्तीनी बच्चों के नाम यह कविता लिखी है जिनकी मासूम जाने एक युद्ध ने ली हैं, वो लड़ाई जिसकी कीमत इन् बच्चों की जान से चुकाई जा रही है। उन तमाम दृश्यों को मैं भूलना चाहती हूंभूलना चाहती हूं बम के धमाके और खून में पड़े बच्चों की लाशमिट्टी के मलवे में धंसी मां को पुकारे जाने की आवाजबच्चों की कांपती देहहर दृश्य मेरे भीतर खौफ पैदा करता हैसोचती हूं कहीं अगर ये मेरा देश होता!अगर ये मेरे बच्चे होते!अगर ये मेरे लोग होते!जानती हूं ये देश मेरा नहीं हैये बच्चे मेरे नहीं हैंसिर्फ ये कह देने से क्या हम मुक्त हो सकते हैं?दुनिया के प्रधानमंत्री अपना- अपना पक्ष रखते हैंबेशर्मी और निर्ममता से कहते हैं कि अस्पतालों पर हुए हमले के लिए हम जिम्मेदार नहींमुझे घिन आती है उनके बयान सेमुझे घिन आती है ऐसे प्रधानमंत्री के चेहरे सेजो समझते हैंदेश उनके पांव के नीचे हैंवे जब चाहें उसे मसल सकते हैंमलवे की ढेर में सोये बच्चे नींद में अपना बिस्तर तलाशते हैंअपना घरवे खिलौने जो पिता ने दिए थेइस बर्बाद देश मेंकौन किसे राहत देंहवा कब्र को सहलाती हैनन्हें बच्चों के कब्र की मिट्टी खून से लाल हैमुझे माफ करना बच्चोंमेरी कविता तुम्हें बचा नहीं सकतीमुझ में कोई बाज़ीगरी नहीं है शब्दों कीये दुख है मेरामैं जानती हूंमेरी कविता लाचार और शक्तिहीन हैतुम कहोगे वो कविता क्याजो बचाती नहीं देश को लोगों कोहां मुझे दुख है मेरी कविताकोई आवाज नहीं देतीवो भी पड़ी है मेरे सिरहानेखून से लथ- पथ Written by our state leader from Bihar, this poem is dedicated to the children of Palestine who are paying the price of a war imposed on them. content: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) 1002- Ansal Bhawan, 16-K.G. Marg, New Delhi-1 29-03-2023 Shri. NARENDRA MODI Hon’ble Prime Minister Union of India Respected Prime Minister, Sub: IMMEDIATE INTERVENTION & ACTION AGAINST K. SURENDRAN, Kerala State President of BJP. We, the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW) are writing this to bring to your noticea serious issue of insulting women by the Kerala State President of BJP K. Surendran. On Sunday 26th March 2023, a convention was held in Thrissur, Kerala, with the purpose of constituting a Reception Committee for the STHREE SHAKTI SAMMELAN as part of G20 SUMMIT. Mr. Surendran inaugurated this convention While addressing the gathering, Mr. Surendran said “women leaders of the Communist Party have become fat by looting money" and “after becoming fat like Poothana, they are insulting the women of Kerala." NFIW views these comments which are sexually coloured, aimed at body shaming and insulting the modesty of women, as an attack not only on those who belong to any particular political party, but the entire country. We deplore Mr Surendran's anti-women comments. We have no doubt that Mr Surendran's words will tarnish the image and prestige of our country which is going to host the G20 Summit in a few months from now. You being the Hon'ble Prime Minister of India and the current chair of the G-20, we request you to urgently initiate appropriate action against Mr. Surendran. content: संभवतः 1973 की बात है , देश में मंहगाई बढ़ रही थी और कालाबाजा़री के चलते व्यापारियों ने बाज़ार से ज़रूरत की वस्तुएं गायब कर दी थी꫰ ऐसे वक्त में मध्यप्रदेश की दो जुझारू, जाँबाज़ नेत्रियों ने कुछ लोगों के साथ मिल कर भोपाल के पुल पुख्ता इलाके से निकलने वाले अनाज से भरे ट्रक पकड़ लिये और जरूरतमंद लोगों को उचित दाम पर बिकवाया ꫰ साथ ही पुराने भोपाल के जुमेराती और मंगलवारा इलाके में गोदामों पर छापे मारे ꫰ फलस्वरूप इन सबकी गिरफ्तारी हुई और 15 दिन की सजा़ भी ꫰पढ़ कर आपको रोमांच पैदा हो रहा है ना, तो यकीनन आप यह जानकर गौरवान्वित भी होंगे कि इन्हीं दोनों महिलाओं ने मध्यप्रदेश महिला संगठन का गठन किया और चूंकि दोनों के उद्देश्य समान थे तो बाद में यह भारतीय महिला फेडरेशन से सम्बद्ध हुआ ꫰ये दोनों नेत्रियां थीं सुश्री मोहिनी श्रीवास्तव जिन्हें सब मोहिनी देवी या मोहन बाई के नाम से बुलाते थे और बेगम अख्तर जहाँ जिन्हें प्यार से छोटे बड़े सभी अख्तर आपा कहते थे ꫰ यह मेरी खुशकिस्मती है या कहूं कि दुनिया मुझ पर रश्क करेगी क्योंकि मैं इन दोनों की उंगली पकड़कर चली हूँ और इनकी गोद में खेली हूँ ꫰1976 से पहले मध्यप्रदेश के अलग अलग जिलों में विभिन्न महिला कमेटियां थीं जो प्रगतिशील विचारों के साथ काम कर रही थीं ꫰ मोहिनी देवी और अख्तर आपा की पहल पर इन कमेटियों को एकजुट करने के उद्देश्य से जून 1976 में मध्यप्रदेश महिला संगठन बना ꫰ जिसका पहला प्रान्तीय सम्मेलन 12-13 जून 1976 को भारतीय महिला फेडरेशन की नेत्री सुश्री प्रमिला लूंबा यानी पिम्मी दीदी के मुख्य आतिथ्य में भोपाल में सम्पन्न हुआ ꫰ सम्मेलन में डाॅक्टर प्रतिभा रमन को अध्यक्ष और सुश्री मोहिनी देवी को महासचिव निर्वाचित किया गया ꫰ कार्यकारिणी में श्रीमति पेरिन दाजी, डाॅ सुशीला माइणकर, अख्तर आपा, डाॅ नुसरत बानो रूही, मुमताज जहाँ, प्रो शकुन्तला प्रधान , जयश्री केतकर, कृष्णा वर्मा आदि को शामिल किया गया ꫰ इन महिला नेत्रियों ने महिलाओं की स्थिति बेहतर बनाने, उनमें जागरूकता पैदा करने के लिए खूब काम किया ꫰ जगह जगह महिला सिलाई केन्द्र और इसी तरह के अन्य केन्द्र खोले गये ꫰ यहाँ महिलाएं अलग अलग हुनर सीखने के साथ ही समय समय पर होने वाली चर्चाओं में हिस्सा लेतीं और आंदोलन में भी शामिल होतीं ꫰इस तरह धीरे धीरे महिला संगठन मजबूत होता गया ꫰ संगठन का दूसरा प्रान्तीय सम्मेलन चार साल बाद 1980 में और तीसरा सम्मेलन 1983 में विमला फा़रुकी जी के मुख्य आतिथ्य में हुआ जिसमें मोहिनी देवी को दूसरी और तीसरी बार भी महासचिव चुना गया ꫰ 1986 में मोहिनी देवी के निधन के बाद महिला संगठन के काम की गति काफ़ी धीमी हो गई ꫰ 1987 में चौथा राज्य सम्मेलन सुश्री तारा रेड्डी जी के मुख्य आतिथ्य में हुआ जिसमें जयश्री केतकर जी को महासचिव चुना गया ꫰लेकिन उनका भी निधन हो जाने से महिला संगठन को काफ़ी नुकसान हुआ ꫰ कुछ समय पश्चात एक राज्य स्तरीयसम्मेलन भोपाल में किया गया जिसमें अख्तर आपा को अध्यक्ष, डाॅ नुसरत बानो रूही जी को उपाध्यक्ष और सुश्री रछपाल कौर को महासचिव चुना गया ꫰ सम्मेलन की मुख्य अतिथि तारा रेड्डी जी थीं ꫰ यहीं म प्र महिला संगठन का नाम बदल कर भारतीय महिला फेडरेशन किया गया ꫰ कुछ समय काम बहुत अच्छा चला लेकिन रछपाल जी के दिल्ली वापस चले जाने के बाद गति एक बार पुनः धीमी हो गई ꫰ हालांकि कई जिलों में सम्मेलन हुए और कमेटियों का गठन भी हुआ ꫰2002 में शहडोल में सुश्री सेहबा फारुकी जी की उपस्थिति में एक क्षेत्रीय सम्मेलन कर रूही जी को अध्यक्ष और गीता शर्मा जी को महासचिव चुना गया लेकिन विभिन्न कारणों स फेडरेशन वो गति नही पकड़ पाया जो पूर्व में थी ꫰तत्पश्चात 11अक्टूबर 2004 को मुझे भारतीय महिला फेडरेशन म प्र की राज्य महासचिव चुना गया ꫰ हालांकि उस समय मैं इस content: The history of NFIW in Assam The emergence of Asom Mahila Sangha has passed 50 years of Struggle since its birth in 1971.Its foundation was closely linked with various and numerous mass struggles, like the socio-economic & political development of the state. One of them, was at the setting up of the First Oil Refinery in Assam, where women and girls students led the movement and were jailed for 2/3 months too. In response to the Oil Refinery movement in Lakhimpur and Golaghat formed women's organising committees. In 1969 women joined the 2nd Oil Refinery movement. So after long Struggle 1971 at the initiative of these leadership a state level conference was held at Guwahati at Karmabir Nabin Bordoloi Hall. The conference formed a state committee where Prof Nilima Dutta of Guwahati University as president and Hena Bora as General secretary, were elected. Hemada Bora and Nilima Rajkhowa were also elected as Joint Secretaries at the same conference. The conference took on and spearheaded major Campaigns like – Literacy Program, controlling price-hike, and the provision of mid day meal in primary schools, among many others. In addition, Prof Priti Barua of Handiqui girls Collage and Kamala Mazumder joined the Assam chapter of NFIW at the 2nd conference of Asom Mahila Sangha in Jorhat. title: Eulogy to a pioneering women’s leader and social revolutionary – Vimla Dang
excerpt: Aastha Dang On the 12th death anniversary of Vimla Dang, I have been given the arduous task of writing about this socio-political revolutionary and her illustrious work. But how does one limit a life
content: Aastha Dang On the 12th death anniversary of Vimla Dang, I have been given the arduous task of writing about this socio-political revolutionary and her illustrious work. But how does one limit a life and its experiences to a few pages or words? Vimla Dang passed at the ripe age of 82 years on 10th May 2009. She is among the many unsung heroes of India who contributed to progressive social change with their sweat and blood. This may be a good reminder for us that the freedom and growth we see today has come out of the hard toil of our preceding generations. Influences in the early years Vimla Dang was born on 26 December, 1926 in Lahore. She was the third child of Autar and Kamala Bakaya. Her mother Kamala Bakaya was one of the first Montessori teachers in the country. Vimla was only three years old, and her youngest sibling six months old, when her mother went to Europe to train to become a Montessori teacher. This was an unheard phenomenon in those times (around 1930). She was encouraged in her endeavours by her husband as well as her natal family in Allahabad, who took care of the all children in her absence. Vimla’s father, Autar, was also a nationalist. He refused to take up any jobs that involved working for the colonial government. His despise for colonial rule was founded in his personal experiences, especially having closely witnessed the Jallianwala Bagh massacre on 13 April 1919. Vimla in her interview states that her father had splashes of blood on his ‘achkan’ from that day and that left a deep impact on his mind. Early influences on Vimla include her elder brothers, Shashi and Ravi Bakaya who became active members in the Left movement in Lahore. The Chattopadhay family also had a major influence on her, especially Mrinalini Chattopadhay, Principal of Ganga Ram School where Vimla studied. Suhasini Jhambekar, the youngest sister of Mrinalini and Sarojini Naidu, who was also the first female member of the Communist Party of India, was a critical influence on the Bakaya family, especially Vimla’s eldest brother Shashi Bakaya. Work in the students' movement Vimla was an active member of the All India Student Federation (AISF) in Lahore. She was a member of the Girls Squad, which also led to the inception of Women’ Self Defense League (WSDL) in the erstwhile Punjab (before partition). WSDL saw active participation from both teachers as well as students in colleges. They created consciousness among women students in various colleges, making them aware about the Second World War, British rule, Soviet Union etc. Another area in which they actively intervened was around the issue of shortage of food and hoarding by ration shops across mohallas in various cities. This was an important step towards building a women’s movement in Punjab. The outbreak of Second World War had caused a lot of upheaval in India, with massive food shortages across the country, especially in places like Punjab and Bengal. Vimla also went to Bengal for fifteen days to help the victims during the famine of 1943. The misery and hunger that met her eyes, especially of the women and children had a long lasting impact on her. It was during her years in the student movement in Lahore that she met Satyapal Dang, a firebrand student activist. Their relationship and later on marriage was founded on the principals of mutual love, respect, determination for the cause of the poor and marginalised and commitment to the communist ideology. Life in Chhehartha, Punjab Satyapal and Vimla got married in 1952. They both decided to settle in Chhehartha and work among the industrial workers in the region. Chhehartha is a suburban industrial town on the outskirts of Amritsar. Since Amritsar had a lot of industries, Chhehartha was populated with workers and their families who were employed in these industries. There was also a strong left movement and trade union presence in the area. Both Vimla and Satyapal wanted to stay with the workers and work with them. Thus, they declined the Communist Party’s offer to take up positions in the Jullandhar party office. Instead, they rented a one room in workers’ colony and started living and working amidst them. While Satyapal settled in Chhehartha in 1952 itself, Vimla joined him two years later. She started off as a cultural worker, working among the women in Chhehartha. However, mobilising these women was not an easy task. Most of them were confined to the homes and wore ghoonghats. 2 Work was initiated through the trade union strikes and worker agitations. Women also spearheaded these strikes. They prepared food for the strikers, and in the General Strikes, also did dharnas and courted arrests. . Punjab Istree Sabha, regional wing of the NFIW in Punjab, under the aegis of Vimla Dang, played a pivotal role in organising the wives, mothers, sisters of the strikers. This was a first time phenomenon, and by doing this they were able to create a massive movement. When imprisonment was courted, then many other jathas, comprising of women also courted arrests, including Vimla Dang.1 It is also worth noting here that while the dowry issue broke out in the national women’s movement only during the 1970’s, regional branches of NFIW had begun work on the issue as early as the 1950s. Among them, Punjab Istree Sabha was very active, and the movement was spearheaded by Vimla Dang. She initiated the anti dowry movement by curbing the practice first among the Communist party members. Vimla and Satyapal Dang used to hold meetings with the male workers and their sons, to educate them about the menace of dowry and prevent them from perpetuating this practice. In fact, they would only attend marriage that happened without dowry and also make a speech during the wedding function to acknowledge that the groom and his family have not taken any dowry. In fact Punjab was one of the first States to have amended the dowry act in the year 1976. Punjab, along with West Bengal, Bihar, Orissa, was also one of the first states to make dowry a cognisable offence. Punjab was also the first state in India to have passed a law that if a woman dies within seven years of marriage, it will be compulsory to have a post mortem examination of body, unless the family gives written certificate that they do not suspect any foul play. The role played by PIS under the aegis of Vimla Dang cannot be undermined in ensuring sustained efforts for enactment of these laws. Role during militancy in Punjab (1980s and 1990s) Over the decades, a lot of social experiments were carried out in Chhehartha that saw their impact in many places in Punjab. However, the most far reaching impact of Vimla Dang’s work was seen during the daunting period of militancy in Punjab through the 1980s and 1990s. The militancy period in Punjab shook the state to its core. During this time, when the demand for a ���Khalistan’ was rampant, there were some voices that resisted these demands even at the cost of threat to their lives. Among them Vimla and Satyapal Dang’s name were notable. Members of the Punjab Istree Sabha went to villages inflicted with militancy. They would use verses from Guru Granth Sahib to argue against the concept of militancy and ‘Khalistan’. Vimla Dang organised protest marches, conducted cultural programmes to keep the people united. NFIW activists from across the country supported the cause. Aruna Asaf Ali herself went to Punjab at the height of militancy to carry out peaceful processions. It was during this time that Vimla Dang pioneered relief work among the families inflicted by militancy. Punjab Istree Sabha Trust was started which provided scholarships and funds for the education of children who had lost their families to militancy. Despite being on the radar of the militant outfits, Vimla Dang never cared for her life. She continued to work zealously towards the cause of ensure peace and harmony in Punjab. Looking at her deep commitment, Aruna Asaf Ali had commented, “This girl (Vimla) is my ideal”. During the 1992 elections when terror was at the peak, she decided to contest elections from the Amritsar West constituency. When many leaders did not contest the elections due to fear for their lives, Vimla contested because she did not want the message to go through that the “Dangs had become fearful of the militants”. She won those elections and continued to work for the cause of women and children during her stint as an MLA. For her unflinching spirit and selfless service, Vimla Dang was also awarded the Padma Shri in the year 1991. In Conclusion It is easy to epitomise the life she led by writing eulogies, but very difficult to have actually lived it. Today, as we battle a fascist government, an all engulfing pandemic, where people are dying gasping for breath, I often think, what would Vimla do in such times? Would her spirit remain unbroken and resolve stand tall? It is difficult to document a life lived so exemplarily in few words, but it is even more difficult to have lived and emerged successful through those experiences. She continues to live with us through her words, her actions, her voice and her spirit through these years. Comrade Vimla ko Lal Salaam! About the writer Aastha Dang is presently pursuing her PhD in Gender Studies from Ambedkar University, Delhi. She has been working for several years in the development sector. content: 21 वीं सदी के, दूसरे दशक का आख़िरी दिन, ये बता/दिखा गया के आने वाले बरस दर बरस "भारत" (हिंदुराष्ट्र) में कॉरपोरेट्स राज की प्रतिस्थापना के लिए "औरताना हथियारों" का इस्तेमाल (खुल्ले तरीक़े से) बख़ूबी किया जाएगा…….!!! हालांकि दौराने जंग, दुश्मन देशों की रणनीति पता करने, उनके भेद लेने के लिए- कई बार सैनिक, पॉवरफ़ुल सफ़ेदपोश, राजनीतिज्ञों, अपराधियों को तोड़ने के लिए बतौर जासूस औरत और शबाब का इस्तेमाल हर दौर में बख़ूबी किया जाता रहा है.आज़ादी से पहले हमारे मुल्क के राजा/राजघराने भी विदेशी मेहमानों/आक्रांताओं से अपने राजपाट या शानो-शौकत बचाने के लिए अपनी बहन, बेटियों के रिश्ते ऐसे ताक़तवरों के साथ करते रहे हैं….ये बात अचंभित करनेवाली मानी भी नहीं जाती..कहावत भी है- "मोहब्बत और जंग में (जीतने के लिए) सब जायज़ है"… 🙃 वैसे तो हमारे मुल्क में करीब 400 बरसों से विदेशी कॉरपोरेट्स की नज़रें रही हैं और हमारी अवाम ने क़रीब 300 बरस ईस्ट इंडिया कंपनी जैसे अनेकों क्रूर कॉर्पोरेट्स की ग़ुलामी झेली है….लाखों क़ीमती जवानियां क़ुरबान करके आज़ादी भी हासिल की है (ये और बात है के ये देश 75 बरस भी आज़ादी की हवा में सांस नहीं ले पाया और दोबारा से विदेशी यहूद की ग़ुलामी का पट्टा गले में पहन लिया है…!ख़ैर…… वापस अपनी बात पर आते हैं…कोरोना काल की बंदी के दौरान बड़ी ही आपाधापी में "रॉयल सीक्रेट सर्विस (RSS)" की मौजूदा केंद्र सरकार ने एक "अध्यादेश" के ज़रिए, भारत के किसानी क्षेत्र के तथाकथित विकास के लिए 3 ग़ैर संविधानिक बिल प्रस्तुत किए और रातोंरात (बक़ौल पीएम- आधीरात को) संसद के दोनों सदनों से पास भी करवा लिया.जब देश के किसान इसे नकारते हुए इन क़ानूनों के नुक़सान गिनाने लगेऔर साथ ही इन्हें रद्द करने और अपने फ़सल के मूल्य निर्धारण का क़ानून बनाने की मांग करने लगे तोसरकार ने बेरूख़ी दिखाते हुए क़ानून वापस लेने से साफ़ इंकार कर दिया….किसान अपने लोकतांत्रिक अधिकार के तहत शांति पूर्ण तरीक़े से विरोध प्रदर्शन करने लगे..सरकार ने ज़िद्दी रुख़ अपना कर उनकी बात सुनने के बजाय उन्हें इग्नोर करना शुरू कर दिया…… नतीजतन, देश के किसानों ने राजधानी दिल्ली की तरफ़ कूच कर सरकार से बात करने का ऐलान कर दिया….सरकार ने किसानों को दिल्ली आने से रोकने के लिए सारे ज़ालिम करमों के साथ सड़कें तक खुदवा डाली मगर किसानों का क़ाफ़िला थमने के बजाय, तमाम (अमानवीय) सरकारी अवरोधों को लांघते हुए बढ़ता रहा….आख़िरकार वे अपने लाओ-लश्कर के साथ दिल्ली के दरवाज़े पहुंच गए….पुलिस के ज़रिए सख़्ती से आगे बढ़ने से रोक दिया गया….अंततः किसानों के क़ाफ़िले ने दिल्ली बार्डर के सड़क पर ही अपना पड़ाव डाला और वहीं बैठ गए…नतीजतन पूरे देश के मेहनतकशों का अपार समर्थन अन्नदाता के पक्ष में खड़ा होने लगा और राज्यों के किसान दिल्ली कूच का ऐलान देने लगे……मौजूदा वक़्त में दिल्ली की सभी सीमाएं दूरदराज़ के किसानों के क़ाफ़िले से सील होने लगी हैं…. देश ही नहीं विदेशों में भी किसानों के समर्थन में भारत सरकार की थू थू होने लगी.सरकार किसी नशेड़ी की तरह उनींदी सी किसानों के ख़िलाफ़ बुरे प्रचार करने/करवाने लगी.उनके आंदोलन को आतंकवादी समर्थित फ़र्ज़ी किसानों का जमावड़ा बताने लगी….सरकार के मंत्री, संतरी और भोंपू मीडिया के ज़रिए उन्हें दलाल किसानों का आंदोलन घोषित करवाने में जुट गए…..लेकिन किसान थे के हाड़ कंपा देने वाली दिल्ली की बर्फ़ीली सर्दी और बारिश अपने पर झेलते हुए, पथरीली सड़क को बिछौना बनाए, आसमान को ओढ़कर, दिन-रात, खुले आसमान के नीचे (40 दिनों से) डटे हुए हैं….यहां रहकर किसान आंदोलन ने उन्हें बदनाम करने वाले, उनकी देशभक्ति पर संदेह पैदा करवाने वाले, उनके ख़िलाफ़ भ्रामक ख़बरें चलाने वाले सरकारी गोदी (प्रिंट/इलेक्ट्रॉनिक) मीडिया का टोटली (सम्मानजनक तरीक़ों से) बहिष्कार कर दिया…..सिर्फ़ यही नहीं बल्कि अपना अख़बार और अपना (अॉनलाईन ) न्यूज़ चैनल भी शुरू कर लिया….जिससे देश दुनिया का अपार जन-समर्थन किसान आंदोलन को मिलने लगा….अब सरकार नींद से जागी….आनन फ़ानन में 5 राउंड बैठकों का सिलसिला चलाने का नाटक भी किया गया…उन्हें भरमाने, बहकाने, लालच देने की जुगाड़ भी ख़ुब चलाए गए…..लेकिन किसान क़ानून रद्द करवाने से कम में राज़ी ही नहीं हुए….दिल्ली दरवाज़ों पर किसान आंदोलन के समर्थन में हर दिन जन सैलाब बढ़ता जा रहा है और सरकार किसी भी क़ीमत पर क़ानून वापसी को अपनी नाक का सवाल बनाए रखने पे अड़ी हुई है….अब जबकि किसानों ने सरकारी गोदी मीडिया के बरअक्स अपना ख़ुद का मीडिया खड़ा कर लिया है और जन-समर्थन लेकर आने वाले हर देशवासी/ संगठन अपने एक अदद मोबाइल+कैमरा के साथ आने लगे हैं जिसकी वजह से जन'प्रचार तंत्र भी दिन-दूनी रात- चौगुनी रफ़्तार से बढ़ता चला जा रहा है…..जिससे उत्साहित किसान भी मज़बूती से टिके हुए हैं…..इससे अब सरकार घबराई सी दिखने भी लगी है…..चूंकि भारत का मीडिया 2 घरानों ( अंबानी, अडानी) के हाथों में पहले ही केंद्रित किया जा चुका था-और मौजूदा किसान आंदोलन के असली दुश्मन भी यही दोनों पूंजीपतियों के सरदार हैं…..किसान आंदोलन की तरफ़ से इन दोनों की कंपनियों के उत्पादों का बहिष्कार के राष्ट्रव्यापी आव्हान के बाद अब इन दोनों को भी बुरी तरह आर्थिक चोटें मारी जा रही हैं…..यही वजह है के अब ये ख़ुद सीधे मुक़ाबले में आते से लग रहे हैं… अंबानी के ख़रीदे गए न्यूज़ चैनलों में से एक (छी न्यूज़) की महिला पत्रकार देशव्यापी किसान आंदोलन में शामिल संगठनों के एक मुख्य घटक संगठन के नेता श्री राकेश टिकैत से बाईट लेने के लिए उन्हें लगभग अपनी बाहों में जकड़कर सवाल करती दिखाई पड़ी है….युवा महिला पत्रकार की इस हरकत से ये साफ़ पता चलता है कि बचे हुए दो गुजरातियों (अंबानी अडानी) में एक अब अपनी महिला कर्मचारियों के ज़रिए किसान संगठनों के नेताओं पर अप्सरा भंगिमाओं के दांव आज़माने के फ़िराक़ में हैं….ऐसा दिखाई पड़ने लगा है के अपने संस्थान में कार्यरत कुछ मेनका अदाओं के ज़रिए किसान आंदोलनों में शामिल संगठनों को बदनाम करने की घटिया हरकत करके, आंदोलन की एकता को तोड़ कर ये किसानों को अपने क़ाबू में करना चाहता है….गुज़रे कल (30 दिसंबर-2020) ज़ी (छी) न्यूज़ संस्थान की तरफ़ से "करवाई" गई ये ओछी हरकत, दुनिया के इतिहास में शायद पहली घटना होगी जिसमें सार्वजनिक तौर पे एक महिला पत्रकार का किसी नेता को बाक़ायदा शारिरिक तौर पर क़ाबू (पकड़) कर सवालों के जवाब देने को मजबूर किया गया हो….! ये घटना कहीं से अचानक घटित हुई नहीं दिखाई पड़ती.. …बाक़ायदा, रणनीति के तहत अंजाम दी जाने वाली इस घटना का एक ख़तरनाक पहलु ये रहा के एक प्रेस आईडी के तीन माइक किसान नेता राकेश टिकैत के मुंह के बिल्कुल क़रीब सटे दिखाई दे रहे हैं…इस घटना को देखते हुए,मौजूदा दौर में मुनाफ़ाख़ोर क्रूर गुजराती पूंजीपतियों के चैनल्स में कार्यरत महिला पत्रकारों की सुरक्षा, उनके आत्मसम्मान और ख़ुद्दारी बनाए, बचाए रखने में गोदी मीडिया उसके घरानों की साख पर कई गंभीर खड़े किए जा सकते हैं….. किन मजबूरियों में जकड़ी महिला पत्रकार ग़ैर पेशेवराना हरकतें करने क तैयार होती हैं… ख़ैर ….ये उनके आपसी का मामले हैं. फ़िलहाल आंदोलनरत् "पुरुष" किसान नेताओं के लिए ये गंभीर चुनौती पूर्ण परंपरा की शुरुआत की गई है- जिससे निबटने की रणनीति भी आंदोलन के नेताओं को बनानी पड़ेगी, क्योंकि ये चलन (ख़ासकर महिला) पत्रकारों में अब बढ़ेगा- बरसों पहले से शॉर्टकट- सबसे पहले, एक्सक्लूसिव दिखाने की होड़ का क्रेज़ भारतीय (सस्ती) पत्रकारिता का पसंदीदा शगल content: Poem by Kaifi Azmi आज की रात बहुत गर्म हवा चलती है,आज की रात न फ़ुटपाथ पे नींद आएगी,सब उठो, मैं भी उठूँ, तुम भी उठो, तुम भी उठो,कोई खिड़की इसी दीवार में खुल जाएगी । ये जमीं तब भी निगल लेने को आमादा थी,पाँव जब टूटती शाखों से उतारे हमने,इन मकानों को ख़बर है न, मकीनों[1] को ख़बरउन दिनों की जो गुफ़ाओं में गुज़ारे हमने । हाथ ढलते गए साँचों में तो थकते कैसे,नक़्श के बाद नए नक़्श निखारे हमने,की ये दीवार बुलन्द, और बुलन्द, और बुलन्द,बाम-ओ-दर[2] और ज़रा और निखारे हमने । आँधियाँ तोड़ लिया करतीं थीं शामों की लौएँ,जड़ दिए इस लिए बिजली के सितारे हमने,बन गया कस्र[3] तो पहरे पे कोई बैठ गया,सो रहे ख़ाक पे हम शोरिश[4]-ए-तामीर[5] लिए । अपनी नस-नस में लिए मेहनत-ए-पैहम[6] की थकन,बन्द आँखों में इसी कस्र[7] की तस्वीर लिए,दिन पिघलता है इसी तरह सरों पर अब तक,रात आँखों में खटकती है सियाह[8] तीर लिए । आज की रात बहुत गर्म हवा चलती है,आज की रात न फुटपाथ पे नींद आएगी,सब उठो, मैं भी उठूँ, तुम भी उठो, तुम भी उठो,कोई खिड़की इसी दीवार में खुल जाएगी । :कैफ़ी आज़मी

content: Demands placed before the Central Government for urgent consideration and redressal-Set up a committee to study gendered impacts of the pandemic and to understand the severity of it on women for making policies and programmes to mitigate it.-50% representation of women should be ensured in ALL ‘Task Force/ Committees for impact mitigation of COVID 19.– Reconstitute, with 50% women members, the ‘task force ‘set up by the PM for mitigationof COVID 19 impact.-For Food Security:--To prevent malnutrition and hunger deaths –Distribute ten kg grains per person along with dal, cooking oil and other essential commodities to all; cardholders as well as non-card holders; no beneficiary identification, conditions and targeting It should be given every month till the pandemic crisis is over.– De-link AADHAAR from ration and pension– Set up decentralised community kitchens with nutritious hot-cooked `food at Village Panchayat/ ward level for the elderly or disabled, pregnant and lactating mothers, school students and young children.-The full amount of maternity benefits Rs.`6,000/- (NFSA 2013) in one installment without any disqualifying conditions. Invest more for women and children to ensure a healthy future generation and labour force.Health:-–Recognize the frontline health workers-ASHA, Anganwadi- as workers and institutionalize them with all rights as workers.-Strengthen primary health centers with all facilities as these are the first point of access to women for their health needs-No privatization of government hospitals. Allocate 6% of GDP for Health.-expansion of healthcare facilities with universal coverage for both COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 patientsEducation:--Ensure quality education for all children– to prevent drop out of students particularly girl student in this era of online education, ensure access of space like community centres with facilities and uninterrupted electricity supply for study to those students belonging to poor and vulnerable communities who live in jhuggies, one room houses, shelter homes etc-Use PMCARE Fund to provide laptops, smartphones, TVs etc to students especially to girls from marginalised and poor sections.– Earmark 8% GDP for educationSocial Security:--Enhance financial support substantially for social welfare measures.– Provide financial support of Rs. 10,000/- to all especially those who lost their livelihood under lockdown and to all vulnerable sections of the society-Rs. 10,000/- as monthly financial assistance to landless agricultural workers (60 million women)Employment– Revert, MGNREGA, back as a demand driven Act and increase reservation to 50% for women; Increase the per day wage to Rs. 600/- and ensure timely payment.– 50 % reservation for women under Prime Minister’s Garib Kalyan Rozgar Abhiyaan, with equal wage rate.– Ensure employment to all and financial assistance of Rs. 10,000/- to all unemployed in urban areas.– Enact an Urban Employment Guarantee Act (UEGA) with provisions of 50% reservation for women, equal wage etc.– 50% of the ‘rented houses’ announced by the PM for migrant workers should be reserved for women workers.SHGs & women farmers:-– Waiving of interest and loans for SHGs taken before the lockdown;– NOT collateral free loan BUT Provide interest free loans to SHGs, women farmers, including those who are in poultry, fishing, dairy etc . उन्होंने अपना काम किया तब मैंने वहाँ चल रहा Nfiw का कार्यक्रम अटेंड किया। उस वक्त मुझे लगा कि कितनी सारी महिलायें दूसरी महिलाओ के लिये कितना कुछ कर रहीं है औऱ हमने अपने जीवन को सम्पूर्ण औऱ सफल समझ लिया है। उस समय कुमुद दीदी के नेतृत्व में पूरा कार्यक्रम चल रहा था। गुना आकर पुष्पराग जी ( मेरे पति )से मैने पूछा कि क्या हम भी गुना में ऐसा कुछ कर सकते है। इन्होंने कहा बिल्कुल कर सकते हो और उनहोंने मार्च आने को था।हमने तय किया कि गुना में जितने अन्य संगठन है उन सभी को बुलाकर महिला दिवस मनायेगे। गुना में जब कोई जानता नही था कि महिला दिवस क्या है तब हम लोगों ने महिला फेडरेशन की स्थापना के साथ पहली गठन किया । हमारे उत्साह का ठिकाना नही था।हमने संगठन की कई राष्ट्रीय मीटिंग्स अटेंड की – कलकत्ता, दिल्ली,हैदराबाद, जयपुर।एक बार हम भोपाल में NFIW मीटिंग में गये । सभी से पूछा जा रहा था कि राज्य सम्मेलन कौन करना चाहेगा।हम बहुत उत्साह में थे हमने कह दिया कि हम करेगे।और तय हुआ कि राज्य सम्मेलन गुना में होगा।जब गुना आकर हमने कहा कि सम्मेलन के लिये हाँ करके आये है । तब हमें होश में लाया गया कि हम क्या title: NFIW Condemns the Divisive Statement of the Prime Minister
excerpt: In the strongest of words and emotions, NFIW condemns the statement made by the Prime Minister that, "Those indulging in arson can be identified by their clothes". The statement reflects the true char
content: In the strongest of words and emotions, NFIW condemns the statement made by the Prime Minister that, "Those indulging in arson can be identified by their clothes". The statement reflects the true character of the Sangh Parivar that Mr. Modi represents, that is Islamophobic, bloody and inhuman. From the mouth of the Prime Minister, the statement is communal, bigoted and unconstitutional. By making such statements, Mr. Modi has defiled the dignity of his office and the constitution that he took an oath on when he assumed the office of Prime Minister. The Citizenship Amendment Act that was pushed through the Parliament and got an overnight signature by the President, is a despicable move to divide the country on grounds of religion, gender and class. The implementation of the Act in Assam has already shown that women have been the worst affected. With the least amount of access to resources, they have been bound by patriarchy to prove their identity. The detention centre in Jorhat, that is exclusively for women, is nearly full, as women have failed to prove their relation to their fathers or husbands or sons or brothers. Coupled with religion, the Act has proven to being an unconstitutional inhuman move to tear the social fabric of the country. A refugee woman from any of the three countries would be fleeing sexual assault, loss of family members, loss of papers, loss of proof of persecution on ground of religion, and would end up in a detention centre without the right to be called a human being. Reality proves that the Home Minister's words are nothing but a pack of lies. His assurance to Indian Muslims that they will be safe are contradicted by the fact that the family of the former president, government employees, armed forces personnel and families who have been living in Assam for generations have been excluded from a Citizen's list, only due to their religion?!!!!! Mr. Modi India has always been a plural multi-cultural country with many religious and regional diversities. Your attempt to communalize the current agitation is an abhorrent idea. If you go around trying to label all violent rioters based on their dress, keep in mind that the world also knows about your uniform and that of the infiltrators who are turning the peaceful protests into armed clashes. Every part of the country that is burning today due to your politics and policies, can be identified by a dress. Waging a war with students reflects the low educational inferiority complex of the political dispensation in power. It is sad that the police too has given up on the values enshrined in the constitution to do their duty of protecting the weak irrespective of religion, class, caste, creed or gender. It is sadder that the political party in power is ready to fight unarmed students on unequal terms for petty political gains. The students are fighting for their rights, the rights of the future generations, for justice, for equality and an inclusive India that was dreamt of by the freedom fighters and framers of the Constitution. Their fault lies in the fact that they are educated, seek knowledge through their institutions and are ready to stand up for the voiceless. Their voices for the human rights of the minorities will not go unheard or unsupported. Repression of student voices by giving it a communal colour reflects the shallowness of the ideology you follow. title: PRESS RELEASE  for JNU Students
excerpt: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) On JNU PRESS RELEASE —————————————- NFIW strongly condemns the brutal crackdown
content: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) On JNU PRESS RELEASE —————————————- NFIW strongly condemns the brutal crackdown on a peaceful march led by JNU students on 18th of November. The Delhi police have betrayed its cowardly character in resorting to such brute violence with unarmed students. We are shocked to hear that Delhi police specifically targeted the women and the PH/VH students. We ask what threat did the unarmed students of JNU who were demanding their democratic right to accessible education pose that they had to be suppressed in such a deplorable manner. NFIW hold the administration of JNU responsible for this brutality as we know that the students of JNU have been striking for weeks, standing firm on their demands and instead of engaging with them, the Vice chancellor has been absconding from his office and avoiding any dialogue. It is deplorable that instead of having the courage to face the students of the University that he heads, Vice Chancellor Mamidala Jagadish Kumar has been issuing threatening notices and releasing warning videos. NFIW unequivocally reject the sham of the progressive fee structure based on economic backgrounds of the students. As a women’s organization we understand the disparate social backgrounds and the myriad challenges that women students have to overcome in order to reach institutions of higher learning such as JNU. A decision that reduces the struggles of women and other marginalized students to just family incomes is a measured move to keep these sections of the society out of institutions of higher learning. We strongly stand by the demands raised by the students of JNU. Free and accessible education is a right of every citizen of this country and not a privilege of a few. The JNU administration must immediately roll back the increased fee structure and the changed hostel manual. The administration must leave its high-handed attitude and initiate a dialogue with the students’ union. We demand that the MHRD must immediately remove the VC of JNU who has refused to meet the student representatives for the last four years. In spite of this the continuation of M J Kumar as VC shows the hidden agenda of this government. JNU is an institution which has for decades preserved the Constitutional value of social justice through mechanism like deprivation points, reservations and a reduced fee structure. If these mechanisms were to be undermined, the very structure of JNU and the academic excellence that it is able to garner would crumble. We understand that the decision to make JNU a more exclusionary university is a calculated move in the current political climate to destroy the democratic culture of debate and dissent within universitiesand establish only a particular ideology in these spaces. This nefarious plan is not acceptable to the JNU students and we assure them that NFIW stands shoulder to shoulder with them in this battle till the end. Annie Raja General Secretary NFIW

title: NFIW statement against RTI amendments
excerpt: The National Federation of Indian Women strongly condemns the amendments to the RTI Act introduced by the NDA government and demands that they be withdrawn with immediate effect. Amendments which will
content: The National Federation of Indian Women strongly condemns the amendments to the RTI Act introduced by the NDA government and demands that they be withdrawn with immediate effect. Amendments which will impact peoples’ fundamental rights must follow due process and be put through extensive debate and discussion by referring them to the appropriate Parliamentary Standing Committees. All draft legislations, including amendments, must be put through the pre-legislative consultation process. The RTI Act is used every year by nearly 6 million citizens of the country. It has proved to be the strongest tool in the hands of ordinary citizens to realize their fundamental right to know. Its also an instrument to check and prevent corruption at all levels particularly at the grassroot. The law’s passage in the Parliament in 2005 was a victory for peoples’ movements and campaigns. The RTI Act has been a great equaliser and has played a major role in empowering women from every section of society whether rural or urban, rich or poor. It has given them a tool which enables them to demand for and realise their fundamental rights. Women have used this law extensively to ensure access to government proclaimed schemes, fight against the inequality inherent in our society, expose corruption and ensure accountability. RTI Act also ensures dignity to women and in turn it gives them a sense of real empowerment. The bill seeks to amend the RTI Act in order to empower the Central Government to unilaterally decide the tenure, salary, allowances and other terms of service of Information Commissioners at the Centre and States. If this Bill is passed as it is then the RTI Commission will become yet another tool, with no powers of its own, of the government in power. This will put our democracy in greater danger. Weakening of democratic institutions will lead to dictatorship. In order to prevent such disasters and save the country, the NFIW demands the strengthening of the RTI Act by filling up all vacancies in Information Commissions immediately. Stopping attacks on information seekers Implementing the Whistle Blowers Protection Act Addressing poor implementation of Section 4 of the RTI Act, which mandates pro-active disclosure of information Withdraw, with immediate effect, the amendments to the RTI Act introduced by the NDA government. title: Farewell Pimmi Di
excerpt: PrimlaLoomba or Pimmiji, as she was fondly called by friends and comrades, was a strong pillar of the women’s movement in India. She was a long time member and leader of the National Federation of Ind
content: PrimlaLoomba or Pimmiji, as she was fondly called by friends and comrades, was a strong pillar of the women’s movement in India. She was a long time member and leader of the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW) and got associated with itsince its early years. Primla Loomba (nee Dhawan) was born on December 24, 1924 in Multan. Her father, Devi Dayal Dhawan was in the judiciary and posted in various places – Sialkot, Ludhiana, Amritsar, and finally in Lahore. Her mother, Lakshmi, was brought up in Jammu and Kashmir as her maternal grandfather was a doctor and Chief Medical Officer of the state. Primla’s schooling was irregular, partly due to her father’s transferable job and partly because she suffered from asthma. She completed her matriculation from Alexandra High School, Amritsar and joined Kinnard College in Lahore. She completed her MA from Government College, Lahore in Political Science, after which, she taught in Hansraj Mahila College and Islamia College for Women in Lahore. In the 1930s, the Nationalist Movement was strong in Punjab with numerous strikes and demonstrations. Vimla Bakaya (later Dang), who was a year junior to Primla, was politically very active and became a close associate of Primla. Along with Oshima Raikhy, they got in touch with Mrinalini Chattopadhyay (sister of Sarojini Naidu) who was Principal of the Gangaram School, and whose house was a meeting ground of political people. Partition changed the course of Primla’s life. She was to go abroad for further studies, but she was sent to Ferozepur to stay with her sister and her brother-in-law, who was posted there. Ferozepur was on the border area and there, along with her friends, she started working in the refugee camps and gave injections to people infected by cholera. Along with other young girls, she also put up cultural shows to resist the RSS propaganda that ‘Muslims should be compelled to go to Pakistan’. In January 1948, her father posted in Simla, was heading an anti-corruption tribunal. He was a liberal and broad minded man, beyond his times, and arranged for Primla to go to the U.S. Shejoined Cambridge, Massachusetts and started working on her PhD thesis on ‘Political Ideology of the Indian National Congress’. However, she could not finish it. On her return to India in June 1950, Primla joined the CPI. She also joined the Deshbandhu College in Delhi as a lecturer. Soon, she fell in love with and married Satish Loomba, a Communist and trade unionist in Jalandhar, where she also shifted in 1954.Along with Oshima Raikhy and others, she built a school there. At the time, prejudice against the Communists was high, so it was difficult for her to get a job in any college. She worked therefore in the All India Radio (AIR) conducting a children’s programme in Punjabi. From 1954 to 1962, Primla was active in the Punjab based mass women’s organisation Lok Istri Sabha, along with Shakuntala Sukhan, Swaran Sharma, Basso and others. They worked both among urban and rural women and created awareness on the Hindu Code Bill. She also worked for promotion of literacy in the Bhargav Camp, also known as Chamar Basti. In 1962, Primla came back to Delhi andstarted searching for jobs. She finally got an offer from the Delhi Public School to set up a branch at R.K. Puram, where she worked for 23 years from 1962 to 1984. Primla’s first political contact in Delhi was Sarla Sharma. For a short period, she became the Vice President of the Delhi Janwadi Mahila Samaj. Later she started working with Vimla Farooqui at the NFIW Central office, regularly coming from her school to the Theatre Communication Building at Connaught Place, from where the office used to function before being shifted to Ansal Bhawan. From 1973 she started editing the NFIW Bulletin and was its editor for many years. Around the time, she also began working in Trilokpuri along with Bulu Roy Choudhury and others. She helped set up literacy centres around Panchkuan and Paharganj areas. After the 1984 anti sikh riots, Primla, along with Kaushalya organised relief work at Kalyanpuri and set up tailoring centres so that women could earn something on their own. In 1985, Primla attended the WIDF Conference along with Tara Reddy. She was also the Indian representative in WIDF headquarters in Berlin between 1986 and 1987. Primla was involved in the day to day functioning of the organisation. She also contributed richly by preparing Commission Papers for NFIW Congresses, particularly on problems of Communalism. Her papers, along with her writings in the NFIW magazine remain as a rich archivefor us. She was also the NFIW representative in the Internal Complaints Committees of many Public Sector Undertakings (PSUs). Also, she was a member of the Aruna Asaf Ali Trust and regularly attended its meetings. As a deeply committed activist and educationist, Primla touched and shaped the intellectual and moral lives of large numbers of young and old women and men. Her work and strength of character remained a source of inspiration for all those who came to know her. When in 1973, she lost the love of her life, her husband Satish Loomba in an airplane crash, she remained a picture of courage and tenacity, and as a single mother, brought up her two young, school going children, Ania and Bindiya. She was a fighter who never allowed herself to become a victim of her circumstances. Few years back, she lost her daughter Bindiya to cancer and was herself undergoing cancer treatment for a long time, but that did not deter her and she continued to be actively engaged with Spring Dales school as well as NFIW. In recent years, she attended many programmes organised by NFIW, such as on ’60-year celebration’, Love Jihad (‘Love and Let Love’), ‘Reclaiming India’ and 33 per cent reservation. She also participated in many joint protests and meetings. As her health permitted, she also came to many office meetings. Even though she never called herself a ‘feminist’, Primla remained however one of the most radical and progressive voice both in the organisation and the women’s movement at large. She was always encouraging and guiding young feminist activists and was abreast with the theoretical debates and practices across the world. A woman of extra-ordinary beauty, Pimmiji always exuded warmth, radiance and strength. Those who know her intimately sing praises about her many other wonderful talents. She was a superb cook and a wonderful seamstress, who tailored all her own clothes to perfection. The tapestries embroidered by her still adorn the walls of many a family member’s homes! Pimmiji’s positive and inspiring presence will be deeply missed, and She will always reside in our hearts. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-6939122175aec', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: President of India has failed the women of India
excerpt: PRESS RELEASE To The Bureau Chief President of India failed the women of India The National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW) expresses its deep disappointment over the address of the President of Ind
content: PRESS RELEASE To The Bureau Chief President of India failed the women of India The National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW) expresses its deep disappointment over the address of the President of India to the joint sitting of Parliament today, the 20th June 2019. While acknowledging the fact that compared to previous elections, the women voters have cast their votes equally with male voters in the 17th Lok Sabha election, the President failed in highlighting the reality that even after seven decades of our independence only 14% members are women in the Parliament of the largest Democracy of the world. Surprisingly the President terms the election of 78 women to Parliament as ‘Picture of New India’. Though the President spoke elaborately on women’s empowerment he confined it to women’s security and centered her around a few schemes like Ujjwala Yojana, Mission Indradhanush etc. He said that the ‘government’s thinking’ promotes not only women’s development but also women-led development. The President continues to say that His Government is committed to make women equal stakeholders in the country’s development and prosperity. NFIW is of the firm opinion that this sort of ‘thinking’ about women’s empowerment from the part of the government is nothing but feudal, Patriarchal and Manuvadi. That is why there is no mention of the passage of the Women’s Reservation Bill in his address. The hugely male dominant Government will decide what is good for the women and when and how they will be empowered and on what aspects. Sadly, the President of India ignored the importance of equal participation of women in decision making in a Parliamentary Democracy. His Government lacks the political will and social commitment to ensure that the decisions are taken collectively by all genders and not exclusively by men. title: Letter to Minister (Ministry of Women and Child Development)
excerpt: 15th June, 2018 From, Annie Raja General Secretary National Federation of Indian Women 1002, Ansal Bhavan, Kasturba Gandhi Marg New Delhi 110001 To, The Hon’ble Minister Ministry of Women and Child De
content: 15th June, 2018 From, Annie Raja General Secretary National Federation of Indian Women 1002, Ansal Bhavan, Kasturba Gandhi Marg New Delhi 110001 To, The Hon’ble Minister Ministry of Women and Child Development. New Delhi Dear Minister, We, members of the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW), have been extremely shocked to read the report in the Business Standard of 14th June 2018, that the WCD Ministry of the NDA Government has asked that the beneficiaries of the ICDS scheme in the country be made to say on camera how grateful they are to the Prime Minister and the Govt. for the benefits they are receiving. We understand that all District and Block level officers have been asked to shoot and send these videos to the Ministry, and they are already being used for purposes of publicity We are disturbed at the very unethical use of power that is being displayed here. All governments, we know, try to take credit for all development work in the country, especially as we enter election year. But we also know that the ICDS scheme and related benefits were planned and implemented by the UPA Government more than a decade ago. The NDA Government has played no role in it, except to roll back some benefits and rename others. In the circumstances we consider this a reprehensible and positively dishonest attempt to appropriate credit for work done by others. It is also a shameful use of the power of government over poor women, made worse by the fact that it is being done by fiat. We therefore request you to immediately withdraw this order and refrain from using videos in which women were clearly coached to say what the officials wanted them to say. It is not just unethical but shows a ruthless, disrespectful use of women who are powerless to protest. Thank you, Annie Raja General Secretary, NFIW __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-6939122c1faa5', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: Press Release for Baatein Aman Ki
excerpt: On 14 June 2018 a formal press conference detailing the Baatein Aman Ki campaign, was held at the IWPC. Women groups from across India are coming together in a campaign conceived to address democratic
content: On 14 June 2018 a formal press conference detailing the Baatein Aman Ki campaign, was held at the IWPC. Women groups from across India are coming together in a campaign conceived to address democratic challenges facing the country. बातें अमन की campaign is planned between September 22 and October 15, 2018, is an effort to galvanize women and men across India to rise against the violence and chaos that has engulfed our country. Five routes have been chalked out. Women's groups and people’s networks in various cities, towns, villages en route will be invited to form local coordination committees and host the groups of women traveling on different routes. National Federation of Indian Women has been fighting exclusion, discrimination and injustice based on gender, religion, caste and class, for decades. However, in the last four years, the battle has been tougher. In its effort to contain the rising tide of communalism and ne-liberal economic destruction, NFIW regularly partners with movements, individuals and organizations working towards the same goal. One such effort is the Baatein Aman Ki. This is the first time in the history of India that large sections of women have been forced into humiliating situations within their own homes due to demonetization as thousands of women lost their livelihood. Demonetization, riots, lynchings, parallel moral police and the overall rise in hate crimes and speeches need to be countered at as many levels as possible. Annie Raja (NFIW), Marium Dhavle (AIDWA), Leena Dabiru and Shabnam Hashmi (India Inclusive) while addressing the press conference pointed out that there is a targeted attack on the Constitutional rights of women in India. A direct attack on the independence of women, has been accompanied by constant effort to psychologically undermine women through systematic propaganda. The growth of violence in society is making a deep impact on the lives of women. Mob lynching by the cow vigilantes, honor killings etc have become a daily affair. Attacks on Muslims, Dalits and Christians are creating an atmosphere of fear and insecurity. This normalization of violence must be stopped. Inspired by the Hitlerian policy of the superiority of colour and race, and in the footsteps of, various outfits of RSS: Garbh Vigyan Sanskar (Uterus Science Culture), Arogya Bharati and Vidya Bharati have been conducting live trials in various parts of the country to produce ‘fair’ and ‘tall’ ‘customised’ children. Like their predecessors they see the role of women as submissive wives and mothers who produce babies of ‘good race’. There is a strong agreement among the conservative clergy of all religions and fascist forces on women’s role in society Under the Modi government, there has been a frontal attack on the Constitution that adversely impacts women. This includes right to dress, speak, write, eat and choose a life partner, rights gained through sustained feminist struggles. In addition, neo-liberal economic policies have not only adversely impacted Indian women in general, but also those of us who are Dalits, Adivasis and people already marginalised in this country. The fragile economic base has been devastated. Women who are from the minority communities – Muslims, Christians and other religious minorities, Dalits, those following a different ideological bent; and all dissenting voices are being attacked on a regular basis with the active support of the ruling party, the BJP. The violence and atrocities by the Indian State against Kashmir's youth and women has exceeded all previous limits. Our women's peace initiative believes that dignity and rights for the Kashmiri people and withdrawal of the military footprint from civilian areas in Kashmir are essential for peace in Kashmir. As women and citizens we have been horrified at the state’s response to the Kathua and Unnao rapes. They have been targeted for political revenge and vendetta. We are witnessing a steady deterioration in the rule of law, and the basic constitutional commitment to equality. The political and religious discourse being created around these rapes are equally unacceptable. Rape is used to polarize people on communal lines. Many Laws like Minimum Wages Act, PWDVA, Dowry Prohibition Act, PCPNDT Act, MGNREGA, NFSA, RTI, etc. that came into existence due to the long struggles by women's movements, are now under attack. There is a conscious effort to negate and destroy these acts. Women constitute 50 per cent of the country's population and there is a crucial need to bring women across the country together to build on the huge political gains that women’s movements have achieved over the last century. Any talk on growth will have to include the larger concerns of equality – political, democratic and socio-economic. Cutting through obscurantism, we need to reestablish and bring back on course the developmental agenda of this country on the grounds of Constitutional guarantees. Annie Raja (NFIW) pointed out that, "In the last four years the position of women in India has been deteriorating at an alarming rate. This is chiefly due to politicizing religion, and bringing religion into politics – where the Hindu right wing organisations are playing a leading role. They have been deciding moral values and ascribing the role of women in society. They have invoked religion with the implicit and often explicit consent of the ruling BJP. ‘She further added,’ this govt has betrayed women in the name of various incentives. The time has come to make our voices louder. Through Baatein Aman ki we will stand against all those forces that are trying to break the country in the name of religious or nationalist sentiments." Marium Dhavle (AIDWA) said, "Stereotypes in the name of tradition imposed on women over the centuries that we have fought against, alongwith the demand for equal participation in public affairs and in public spaces, and establish ourselves in the context of an empowered democratic India is at stake." She further added, "Moreover, needs of the people are not fulfilled. 7000 people dying daily of hunger in India mainly women and children. One third of hungry people of the world are in India. In Jharkhand, if a person has died due to hunger the government will conduct post mortem to assess whether they have died of hunger or not. In the name of culture and tradition, women are pushed further. The concept of RSS that women should be at home is being propagated." Shabnam Hashmi (India Inclusive) said, "Women are deeply concerned by the growing violence in the country and all major women groups and people’s movements are joining hands together to spread love and peace. It is for the first time perhaps since the freedom struggle that women are coming together not for talking about women rights only but about the country as a whole and all problems faced by different sections of the people including farmers, students, unorganized sector, professionals , women, adivasis, Dalits and minorities and safeguard the Indian constitution. She said fascist forces are taking over and this campaign will be taking the forces of hatred on the ground as well as fighting the atmosphere of fear.” Leena Dabiru (India Inclusive) talked about the need for women to rise and fearlessly fight against the onslaught on the constitutional values. She told media that a large number national networks, individuals and local organisations are joining the campaign. She detailed all the five routes of the Baatein Aman Ki campaign to the media. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-6939122d3ee33', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: Press Statement on POCSO ordinance
excerpt: 22 April 2018 Succumbing to a populist demand by some sections, Modi government yesterday passed an ordinance for changes in the POCSO Act awarding death penalty to rapists of children below 12, that
content: 22 April 2018 Succumbing to a populist demand by some sections, Modi government yesterday passed an ordinance for changes in the POCSO Act awarding death penalty to rapists of children below 12, that has been signed by the President today. As usual there was no study conducted to ensure that it was a feasible option or if there could be better alternatives. National Federation of Indian Women is appalled by the tampering of the POCSO Act of 2012 that was formulated in order to effectively address sexual abuse and exploitation of children. We would like to point out that the government is covering its incompetence. It lacks the political will to tackle the issue of crimes against women and children. The Death Penalty is a face saving move by a party that has the largest number of sexual offenders in its rank and file. A Party that shields it's own members who are charged with rape and murder to talk of death sentences is hypocrisy. When a party unable to censor its own members from telling women not to eat chowmein, carrying a mobile phone or publicly humiliating Nirbhaya's mother, decides of pass ordinances, it does not show a commitment to the cause of ensuring the safety and security of women. Rather it shows the party's desperation to win another election. Studies have proven that death penalty for crimes like rape or sexual assault do not work as a deterrent to the crime. An effective implementation of existing legislation is needed more than extreme rhetorical steps. The need of the hour is to sensitize the work with civil society organizations to create public awareness about the legal provisions for safeguarding children and women from heinous crimes. The demand of the women's organization for an effective implementation of the Verma Commission report, proper utilization of the Nirbhaya Fund to run sensitization programmes regarding sexual violence with the police and the public, have not been heeded. The government lacks sincerity in bringing about simultaneous judicial and police reforms to ensure that there are enough fast track courts in each district of the country, to tackle the problem. It lacks the honesty to ensure that the large number of pending cases are dealt with speedily and justly. The country has a large number of pending cases and a very low conviction rate, pointing to the level of corruption at the political level when it comes to dealing with offenses against women and children. NFIW would like to see the Prime Minister detailing a plan for the utilization of the Nirbhaya Fund. We demand a proper budgetary allocation for the implementation of the existing Laws that are aimed at protecting the Constitutional rights of women and children. We want an end to such populist measures. If the government is serious, it should cancel the membership of the Legislative Assembly of the two Ministers who have been brazenly supporting the rapists and communalizing the issue in Kathua. We want a commitment to ensure that Unnao and Kathua are never repeated. We want the government to penalize those who support criminals by taking out rallies with tricolours honouring and defending the offenders. We want to see tangible action against the police connivance that killed the Unnao victim's father in custody. Mere passing of populist ordinances is not a solution. Annie Raja (Gen. Sec.) title: An AppealTo  Members of the Electoral College for  India’s Presidential Elections
excerpt: 22 June 2016 India will be electing its 14th President in July this year. We voice the concerns of the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW), its members, and sympathizers for electing a person c
content: 22 June 2016 India will be electing its 14th President in July this year. We voice the concerns of the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW), its members, and sympathizers for electing a person capable and committed to protect constitutional guarantees in the upcoming Presidential elections. The President of India as the Head of State has immense executive, legislative and military powers as defined by the Constitution. S/he enjoys powers to appoint and remove high Constitutional authorities, including the Prime Minister. All appointments of the Judges of the Supreme Court and the High Courts, the State Governors, the Attorney General, the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG), and the members of the election commission are made in his/her name. S/he is also the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces. Therefore the President’s every decision has a far reaching and significant impact on the nation. India is witnessing the systematic undermining of constitutional guarantees in many ways. Equality, the right to freedom of expression and choice, discrimination and victimization of minorities, Dalits, adivasis and women, are increasing both conceptually and in cascading acts of violence. The country is now ruled by fear. The defense and propagation of backward traditional practices by the religious extremists, fostered by the silence of the state, promotes misogynistic mind sets and patriarchy. The revival of Manusmriti threatens equality for Dalits and women and secular, democratic values. The increased violence against women in all forms, is a direct consequence of the revival and tacit approval of regressive traditional practices. The last three years have seen a brazen growth of such attitudes – the situation in UP after the elections is an obvious and glaring example. All the progress achieved by women in defeating patriarchal forces since independence now stand threatened with the Romeo squads, love jihad, honour killings and vigilantism which continue unchallenged. There are reportedly moves to organise meetings to amend the constitution and to make India a Hindu theocratic state, threatening the equality considered essential for the well being of its multiple religions and the plurality of its culture and people. Dissent and difference will be disallowed, and there is every possibility that values that have evolved over thousands of years will perish. The Constitution itself could thus be changed to become a tool of oppression and exclusion. We therefore urge you to unanimously support only those candidate who will uphold the constitution and its secular and democratic values; and thereby be worthy to be considered for becoming the President of India. title: SEVEN DECADES FOR 12%; HOW LONG FOR 33%
excerpt: National Seminar on Two Decades of the Women’s Reservation Bill 12th September 2016 marks the twentieth year of the introduction of Women’s Reservation Bill in Parliament. The Women's Reservation Bill
content: National Seminar on Two Decades of the Women’s Reservation Bill 12th September 2016 marks the twentieth year of the introduction of Women’s Reservation Bill in Parliament. The Women's Reservation Bill, which seeks to reserve one-third of all seats for women in the Lok Sabha and the State Legislative Assemblies was introduced on 12th September 1996 as 81st Constitutional Amendment Bill by Deve Gowda Government. In 1998 the Bill was re-introduced as the 84th Constitutional Amendment Bill by the Atal Bihari Vajpayee Government. In 1999 the NDA government re-introduces the Bill. In 2003 the Bill was introduced twice in Parliament. But all these Bills were lapsed with the dissolution of their respective Lok Sabha. In 2008 the UPA government tabled the Bill in the Rajya Sabha to save from getting it lapse. On 9th March 2010 the Bill was passed by the Upper House of Parliament, the Rajya Sabha. The 1996 Women’s Reservation Bill recommended that reservation will be provided for women of Other Backward Classes (OBCs) once the Constitution was amended. It also recommended that reservation be extended to the Rajya Sabha and the Legislative Councils. Neither of these recommendations has been incorporated in the Bill which was introduced as the Constitution (One Hundred and Eighth) Amendment Bill, 2008 by the Congress led UPA government. It, however, seeks to reserve one-third of all seats for women in the Lok Sabha and the state Legislative Assemblies. Out of the total number of seats in the Parliament, 543, one-third (124) is reserved for Schedule Castes (80) and Schedule Tribes (44). The present Bill ensures one-third seats for SC/ST women from out of these reserved 124 seats. This will be the same in case of State Lagislative Assemblies. On the occasion of the 20th year of the introduction of the Bill the National Federation of Indian Women (NFIW) organized a National Seminar on “Two Decades of Women’s Reservation Bill” at the Constitution Club, VP House, New Delhi on September 12, 2016. The Seminar had two sessions in which women from 15 states participated. Annie Raja, General Secretary, NFIW gave the introductory address. She spoke of the pressing need for women’s reservation in legislatures. She pointed out that even after seven decades of Independence there are only 12 per cent women in the Parliament. She highlighted the role of NFIW in carrying this struggle forward through campaigns, protests and public meetings and emphasised that men and women have to work together for the passage of this Bill. Session I The first session was presided over by NFIW Vice President Dr Gargi Chakravartty. She said in India women’s groups took a stand against reservation during the preparation of the ‘Towards Equality’ report in 1973. The simple reason was that they all believed and hoped that over a period of time women’s presence in the legislatures will increase on its own. But that hope was belied in the coming years as all political parties, including left parties failed to encourage women candidates for elections. The need for reservation therefore became evident. She also noted how India fares the worst among the South Asian countries on the issue of women’s political representation. While India has only 12 per cent women in the Parliament, Bangladesh has 20 per cent, Pakistan 28 per cent and Afghanistan 28 per cent. Scandinavian countries have much higher representation because they introduced reservation long back. Amarjeet Kaur, National Secretary of All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC), and former General Secretary of NFIW (1999-2002) in her inaugural address narrated key moments from the history of the women’s movement in India and the role of NFIW. The freedom struggle saw participation of large numbers of women and the emergence of several women leaders. One such Gandhian leader, Aruna Asaf Ali, who was very active during the Quit India movement, became the President of NFIW in early sixties. From the initial years to now, NFIW has worked very closely with the Women’s International Democratic Federation (WIDF), a socialist institution that addressed the question of gender in its wider social, political, economic and cultural context. A number of NFIW leaders served on important positions within WIDF, and this body was instrumental in advocating for the recognition of Women’s Day in the United Nations (UN) in 1975. The UN held a number of important international conferences, including in Mexico (1975), Nairobi (1985) and Beijing (1995) which saw massive participation from India and elsewhere. It was in the Beijing conference that Indian govt. made a commitment to reserving 33 per cent seats for women in the Parliament. Later, Geeta Mukherjee, a Lok Sabha member from CPI pushed for the passage of the Bill for reserving 33 per cent seats in Union and State Legislatures. A nationwide campaign was done by women’s organisations through debates and events in educational and other institutions. The Bill was passed in the Rajya Sabha but during its discussion in Lok Sabha, it was opposed by a number of members, prominently Uma Bharti, on grounds that it did not include reservation of OBCs. The Bill hangs in limbo, even as the young generation today is in support for the same. Amarjeet recollected the International and National role played by NFIW in the struggle for gender equality and women’s empowerment in every sphere. The leadership at different point of times brought the women’s movement together in this fight. For the passage of Women's Reservation Bill Geeta Mukherjee worked hard as the Chairperson of the Select Committee and played a leading role both inside and outside Parliament. Therefore the fight needs to continue, a fight that is not against men but against patriarchal thinking. Gopal Guru, a Professor of Political Science in the Jawharlal Nehru University (JNU) spoke about 'Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and Women's Rights'. Ambedkar said the rights are not rights till they are exercised. Referring to Women's Reservation Bill he strongly favoured the system of rotation and said the argument of nurturing a constituency by the elected person is not appreciated as the person is elected for a specific period and will have to work for the people of the constitutency for that specific period. He underscored that the women’s question has been addressed by a number of important figures in modern history, both men and women. But non Brahminical people like Jyotiba Phule, Tarabai Shinde, Ramabai Ranade and B.R.Ambedkar have taken very radical stands on the same. He noted the immense contribution of Ambedkar in drafting the Hindu Code Bill which gave all women the right to inter caste marriage, divorce, maintenance and inheritance. Prof Guru then explicated the importance of ‘right’ versus ‘opportunity’. The Constitution gives women a right to raise their voice against patriarchy, but a right only becomes a right if it is exercised. And right can only be exercised if there is an opportunity, which is given by reservation. Women’s reservation is therefore a critical step in promoting women’s rights in all spheres. But it is opposed by those political representatives who don’t wish to give up their power. To address this, a rotation system should be introduced so that a Member of Parliament cannot sit for successive terms.

The PC PNDT has been brought through numerous struggles by Indian women and their organisations to stop sex determination due to a patriarchal mind set. The Minister must make all effort to see that the implementation of this Act is done properly. The women who work as ASHA must be given worker status and all the benefits as workers, not as volunteers The move to make sex determination is nothing but a ploy to serve vested interest in the country. In the name of increasing hospital deliveries, this move will result in genocide of women.
