title: From Women’s Watch of April 2015
excerpt: Is Child Labour a Permanent Arrangement? Sonali Biswas June 12 is observed every year as the International Anti-Child Labour Day. In our country also the day has been marked by Ministers giving a floo
content: Is Child Labour a Permanent Arrangement? Sonali Biswas June 12 is observed every year as the International Anti-Child Labour Day. In our country also the day has been marked by Ministers giving a flood of assurances to ban child labour. However child labour continues to persist from time immemorial. In fact child labour is an old system of exploitation. Leafing through the pages of history one finds that children were employed in different jobs in various times in Europe and America. According to a statistical data of the 17th Century, two-third of the workers happened to be children in 143 textile factories in England and Scotland. The era of Queen Victoria was notorious in this regard. Child labour was rampant in glass factories, mining, cleaning chimneys etc. At the beginning of the 19th century, child labourers below the age of 15 numbered 10 lakh 70 thousand in different American industries. It is known that eminent literatteur Charles Dickens was forced to work in a shoe-polish factory at the age of 12 due to the impoverishment of his family. According to Karl Marx, British industry flourished because of extraction of child labour and thereby transferring capital to the American economy. It was after the Industrial Revolution, when the working class started organising for their rights, that the ideas of universal education and rights of children were discussed and the issue of child labour created a worldwide debate. As a consequence at the end of the 19th century and beginning of the 20th century child labour was prohibited in the developed nations of Europe and America. International organisations such as ILO took different initiatives to control and curb child labour. According to ILO, child labour is “a violation of fundamental human rights”. In 1989 at the UN’s Convention on the Rights of the Child, Article 32 was passed, which proclaims “state parties recognise the right of child to be protected from economic exploitation and from performing any work that is likely to be hazardous or to interfere with the child’s education or to be harmful to the child’s health or physical, mental, spiritual, moral or social development.” Most countries including India endorsed this declaration. However in many of the developing nations like India and in underdeveloped countries, child labour still exists due to socio-economic and other reasons. According to the ILO’s data of 2015, the number of child labourers in the entire world is 12 crores. India happens to be a country with a huge number of child labourers. According to a study by CRY, child labour in urban areas of India has increased by 53% during 2001-2011. Earlier in 1986, the Union Government passed the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act which considered those below 14 years of age as children and according to the Act, they are not to be employed in any kind of hazardous job. Secondly, all children till the age of 14 are entitled to free and compulsory education. This Act has its failings and various organisations have been fighting for redressal of its flaws. UPA Government in 2012 introduced the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Bill in the Rajya Sabha, which recommended a total ban on child labour till children complete elementary education, which was guaranteed under the Right to Education (RTE) Act of 2009. However the present Union Government is planning to amend this Act and that seems to be more dangerous. The prevention of Child Labour Act, 2012 with amendments will be placed in the coming winter session of the Parliament for final endorsement. According to this new Bill, children below 14 years are prohibited employment except in family enterprises, but only after school hours or during vacations and that would exclude any kind of hazardous job. Children are, however, allowed to work in advertisements, films, TV serials etc, only with necessary protective security arrangements, but not in circus. This amendment has created countrywide controversy. Many social activists think that conditional opportunities will increase the rate of child labour. According to Altamas Kabir, the former Chief Justice of India, this would unfortunately recognise and endorse child labour. Social activists feel that since the issue of family business has not been elaborately explained, this might increase indiscriminate use of child labour. This amendment has dented the children’s right to education. There is an apprehension that children will work at family enterprises at the expense of schooling. Working after school hours will affect children’s time for leisure, play, homework. There is also ample chances of exploitation of child’s labour in the guise of technical skill. There is a link between school and labour and unless one ensures better quality of schooling, i.e. teaching and learning, it will be difficult to curb child labour. In the context of globalisation and neo-liberal economy, foreign capital and corporate houses have been flourishing. India is open to that economy. We have already seen that GAP Incorporation, Primark or Walmart – such multinational companies make use of cheap labour like child labour in Asian countries. This is evident in the textile and fabric industries. In the name of family business is not child labour being brought back? Besides in Karnataka, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, where BT cotton is cultivated, child labour is being used as cheap labour. Almost 80% child labourers work in rural areas and three out of four of them work in agriculture or home-based work. The present Prime Minister Narendra Modi has visited 18 countries in 53 days (till first week of June) in his one year rule, but mainly to seek foreign capital for investment in India, and not for enhancing any political solidarity. One condition for foreign capital is cheap labour, and what could be cheaper than child labour? While writing this article it reminds me of the mangled bodies of children, burnt in the fire cracker factory in Pingla. Those children had lost their childhood much earlier, and now they have literally lost their lives. The present bill is silent about a vulnerable age group between 15 and 18. We need to demand complete ban on child labour, including bonded labour, beggary etc. The Government does not have any obligation to eradicate poverty. Its only objective is to hold on to power in whatever way possible. Businessmen and capitalist forces are being appeased with lucrative deals by the Government with the aim of purchasing votes. How many child labourers lose their lives – does it matter to the Government? There is no element of conscience. Therefore child labour perpetuates as a permanent arrangement either through the backdoor or frontally. (The author, a Trade Union activists, is a senior member of the NFIW) __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-69391245f0adc', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: Open Letter to Mr. Kejriwal
excerpt: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) 1002-Ansal Bhawan, 16 K.G.Marg, New Delhi —————————————————————————————- 23 January 2014 To Shri Arvind Kejriwal Chief Minister Delhi. Date: January 21, 2014
content: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) 1002-Ansal Bhawan, 16 K.G.Marg, New Delhi —————————————————————————————- 23 January 2014 To Shri Arvind Kejriwal Chief Minister Delhi. Date: January 21, 2014 OPEN LETTER ON ROLE OF DELHI LAW MINISTER Dear Shri Arvind Kejriwal, It is with extreme dismay that we write to you regarding the horrific act of harassment and racial profiling of Ugandan and Nigerian women by a group led by Delhi Law Minister Shri Somnath Bharti, comprising amongst others members of Aam Admi Party. Such a targeting goes against the sense of security and human rights of all women in general, and of single and working women in particular. Television footage of the incident including Shri Somnath Bharti’s own detailed statements, CCTV footage from AIIMS and the complaints by the women themselves, clearly indicate that Shri Somnath Bharti endangered the women and instigated the crowd to violate their human rights, by branding them as prostitutes and asking the crowd to catch them. We as women’s organizations who have worked amongst women for several decades in Delhi and around, have fought against the extremely insensitive anti-women behaviour of Delhi Police in cases related to crimes against women. Examples of police hostility against women abound—be it cases of “honour” crime where the police has handed over young couples to be killed by their families, or cases of rape and dowry where the survivors are victimized and harassed while the perpetrators roam scot-free. It is increasingly becoming a very unsafe city for women and girls. We agree that it is essential to put in place measures to discipline and hold Delhi police accountable for their lapses and short comings – the latest instances including the Danish woman’s rape and the dowry murder of Neha Yadav. We once again reiterate our long standing demand that the central government take urgent necessary steps towards bringing Delhi police under the Delhi government. We also know how hard it is to ensure that Police act in accordance with law and Constitutional values rather than public or political sentiment, especially in matters involving women and vulnerable social groups. In this incident, the Malviya Nagar SHO became a rare exception who acted to protect the African women, whose safety was criminally compromised.’ It is therefore a great disservice to women’s rights to penalise Police officers who refuse to act in accordance with inflamed prejudices of the public or political leaders. And it is even more dangerous to allow private individuals or even ministers to take the law into their own hands and subject already vulnerable sections like women to further harassment. This was also a clear case of racial profiling against foreign citizens. We are therefore shocked to see you and other leaders of your party defend the actions of Shri Somnath Bharti. We urge you to immediately condemn the role of and take appropriate action against Shri Somnath Bharti and registration of cases against those responsible under relevant sections of the IPC and CrPC. We also demand that you drop the insistence on suspending the Malviya Nagar SHO. We would also like you to meet our delegation at your convenience. title: Press Release
content: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) 1002-Ansal Bhawan, 16 K.G.Marg, New Delhi —————————————————————————————- 14.12.13 Mahila Congress Vice President Ms. Bindu Krishna addressing the NFIW dharna on its 19th day, assured the gathering that the Congress Party, especially its President Ms. Sonia Gandhi, were keen to pass the Women’s Reservation Bill in this winter session of Parliament. Ms. Eve Ensler, renowned playwright and feminist spearheading the One Billion Rising movement worldwide, and Ms. Kamla Bhasin of Sangat, leading the movement in South Asia, also joined the dharna today, to express their solidarity. They reiterated the fact that Denial of Justice amounts to Violence against Women. Ms. Kamla Bhasin pointed out that 40% of Indian married men indulged in spousal violence and were therefore criminals. Denying women the right to exist by withdrawing human rights from them were forms of violence that are dominant in India. They urged the women to rise and demand justice. There was large participation of members of NFIW from several states including Manipur, Haryana, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu and Punjab. Representatives from all the states spoke of the situation of women in their region and the work of women in Panchayat. Ekta Prishad too expressed its solidarity with the demand through its representative Ms. Pushpa. She spoke of the need for land rights for women. The National Federation of Indian Women is holding a 21 day Dharna at Jantar Mantar from November 25 to December 16, 2013 with the main demand being passage of the 33% Reservation for Women in Parliament and Legislative Assemblies. The inaugural day coincided with the International Day for Violence against Women. Each day of the agitation will address the various aspects of violence against women, with the main theme being “Denial of Rights and Justice is Violence”. Issues of poverty, land rights, employment, women workers in the unorganized sectors, food and water security, health services, education, dowry and female foeticide, domestic violence and sexual violence are being discussed over the 21 days. A public meeting will be held on 16th December, the last day of the dharna. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-69391251101c5', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

content: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) 1002-Ansal Bhawan, 16 K.G.Marg, New Delhi NFIW General Secretary, Annie Raja, Baba Adhav of Pension Parishad, Nikhil Dey of MKSS and Akhila Sivadas of CFAR met Ms. Selja Kumari, Minister for Social Justice and Empowerment and urged her to take up the matter of universal pension for the elderly, with a minimum pension of Rs. 2000 in the forthcoming session of Parliament. Annie Raja informed Ms. Selja Kumari of NFIW’s 21 day dharna for 33% Women’s Reservation Bill, a long standing demand of the women’s movement, and urged her to give the matter priority in this Winter Session of Parliament. The Minister supported the demand and assured the delegation that she would take the matter up with Mrs. Sonia Gandhi and other colleagues in the Cabinet. The National Federation of Indian Women is holding a 21 day Dharna at Jantar Mantar from November 25 to December 16, 2013 with the main demand being passage of the 33% Reservation for Women in Parliament and Legislative Assemblies. The inaugural day coincided with the International Day for Violence Against Women. Each day of the agitation will address the various aspects of violence against women, with the main theme being “Denial of Rights and Justice is Violence”. Issues of poverty, land rights, employment, women workers in the unorganized sectors, food and water security, health services, education, dowry and female foeticide, domestic violence and sexual violence will be discussed over the 21 days. Various aspects of violence against women through denial of their rights were discussed today, the 9th day of the dharna, primarily through experiences of the NFIW members from the States of Gujarat, Punjab and Tamil Nadu. The recurrent theme that emerged was unless women were in a position to make decisions in governance, there would be no change in their status. Anjali Bharadwaj of Satark Nagarik Sangathan and co-convenor of the NCPRI spoke of the need for women’s representation and participation in parliament. She particularly stressed on the need for accountability and transparency in all spheres of public dealings of the government. She spoke of how women can empower themselves by using the RTI Act to demand access to basic services that are due to them. She also spoke of how the system prevalent today does not allow for any action on complaints by the common man – instead they are harassed and in many cases beaten up. She emphasized the need for laws for grievance redressal and whistle blowers protection. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-693912525d54b', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: The 6th Day of the Dharna
excerpt: Understanding Violence The sixth day of the 21 day Dharna led by NFIW demanding the passing of the Women's Reservation Bill in parliament was a day dedicated to understanding violence in various forms
content: Understanding Violence The sixth day of the 21 day Dharna led by NFIW demanding the passing of the Women's Reservation Bill in parliament was a day dedicated to understanding violence in various forms. The focus was on how justice is denied to women and the denial of justice is violence. For this the participants in the Dharna, who represent various groups from across the country, shared the kind of violence against women that was predominant in their areas. They used different means of communication to showcase their point. The women from Andhra Pradesh danced to folk songs to show how liquor was destroying the family unit and leading to women being physically assaulted, while the participants from Delhi and Gujarat made folk songs about the atrocities being perpetuated on women. The reservation in decision making processes would ensure a place in the sun for the women, according to the participants. Listing the kinds of injustices being meted out to women in their states, the women complained of three major points. First, was the deafness of the administration and government to the problems faced by women. The apathy shown by the governments aggravated the injustice faced by the women. The second was the ignorance and lack of education of the women. The third, was the need for the state to understand its rsponsibility and protect the weaker sections of society. The women representatives from Andhra Pradesh, including Ms. Jyothi, Ms. Srijanya and Ms. Swati discussed the growing domestic violence in their state. The proliferation of illegal liquor icreased the violence that it caused is growing to gangrenous proportions. They talked of thousands of villages in the state that do not have an access to clean drinking water, but are overflowing with liqour supplies and factories. Liquor is cheaper than food in most areas. Women's organizations have been picketing in places where the problem has grrown to unmanagable proportions. Though they have been able to make a dent, there are over two lakh liquor related violence cases that were recorded by activists, but the police refused to register them. Worse, the government can look at the statistics, but refuses to take action against the liqour kilns or the illicit liquor trade. Acid attacks sounded like a repeat of the alchohol problem in the state. The acid attacks showed the free availability of the chemical. The government is aware of the increasing attacks, but has not tken any action, by either attempting to ban the open sale of acid or formulating punishments for the crome. As long as they get a revenue, or the politicians get a kickback, they are ready to turn a blind eye to the poverty and violence that the alchohol is causing. The representatives from Gujarat, led by Ms. Pushpa, talked of a similar kind of struggle they had to wage in their state. The levels of fear and ignorance were increased largely due to the government inputs. The government in Gujarat is intrumental in creating and spreading lies. It shleters criminals like Asa Ram Bapu and his son Narayan Swami. The rhetoric perpetuating women as weak has led many women to follow the path of supersition. They are being used to perpetuate patriarchal mindsets. In the process the more important problems are getting sidelined. The state has one of the largest number of malnourished women and children in the country. There is acute unemployment. The employement of Rs. 2500 a month for 5 years cannot be counted as development, as it is available to only a limited section of the population and a stagnant pay for a fixed period of time is not indicative of development. The caste and communal problems of Gujarat are also larger than what they seem to be. Dalits in South Gujarat do not have any access to civic amneties. The Dalits and muslims have been pushed into specific areas and have been left out of the process of development. Within the last 10 years, the two have had to deal with coercion and violence. If there are no riots in Gujarat, or if the Dalits and minorities have not sought justice for sporadic violence inflicted on them, it is only because they do not want state repression. All the delegates from Gujarat did not shy away from calling Modi a liar and thug. According to them, there is a deliberate attempt to keep the people illiterate and unaware. Schemes like the mid-day meal are implemented, but the anganwadis and balwadis do not have teachers. The number of schools is being limited and accessibility to them is made formidible by hiking the fee structures or raising the cost of books. The more backward the population, the richer the industrialists and vested political interests become. As pople are not aware of their rights or facilities provided for them, they end up at the receiving end of the rampant corruption that is overtaking the administration. Discussing the problems of the women in their states with the guest speakers, Dr. Sunila Singh and Ms. Bullu Raychowdhary, the delegates from Delhi and Bengal, along with the others, sought a need for social and political change in the country. They sought an economic and administrative empowerment of women to ensure that they do not remain a marginalized section of society. The delegates from Andhra sought seperate police stations manned by women; the women from Gujarat wanted women in administration to combat the corruption; the women in Delhi wanted a platform where the voices of all women (rich or poor) could be heard and all women were united in seeking a share in the decision making process of the country. Significantly, Dr. Sunila Singh, when talking of injustice being a denial of rights and violence, gave the example of women in Haryana who were not allowed to acquire any form of government identity cards in their hometowns. Single women were not allowed to acquire a voter ID card. Denial is injustice; denial is violence, denial is a violation of human rights. Governments are elected and people are taxes for services to be provided to the people. Denial of services is a violent injustice. If the children in an area are denied education, if the adults are denied employment, if human beings are denied civic amneties …. it is a violence against which the country needs to stand up. The patriarchal and corrupt midset will work towards compartmentalizing violence. It will look at rape on the roads as violence, but not martial rape. It will identify some violence and not acknowledge the other, particularly those that do not leave physical scars, as violence. Women who bear the worst brunt of the political, physical and mental violence, will need to understand the phenomena in all its dimensions. Adding to the debate, Trade Unionist Ms. Bullu Chowdhary, pointed out that by seeking a reservation in legislative bodies, women are simply asserting their right to exist. They are saying that they are alive and need to be treated as humans. Though they form 50% of the population, they are never given their due recognition. They are marginalized economically, socially and politically. The reservation will give the women a voice. There was an unequivocal demand for the Women's reservation bill to be to passed in the Parliament. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-69391253957ac', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

content: The fifth day of the NFIW led dharna seeking the Women's Reservation Bill being passed in the next session of Parliament. The focus of the deliberations on the fifth day was 'Opression of Dalits and Tribals'. As is being repeatedly pointed out all the themes being discussed during the dharna are reasons why women need a bigger role in the decision making processes of the country. The marginalized sections of society have been at the receiving end of history and contemporary economic discrimination. Dalits and tribals not only have stigmas pinned to them, but they also face the violence of injustice perpetuated by the state and the stronger sections of the community. The women in these sections face the brunt of discrimination in the worst possible forms imaginable. Paul Divakar, of National Campaign on Dalit Human Rights (NCDHR) while addressing the gathering talked of rape being used as a weapon to subjugate a caste or a community. The heinous crime is a tool of patriarchy and caste. The weapon of rape is used to put people in place, to tell a section of society that they have no rights as equals, to quell any assertion of identity. Historically too, whenever the stronger sections of society wanted to teach a Dalit, or a community to behave themselves, rape was the mode the dominant castes used. Sexual assault on women of the marginalized sections of society is an injustice not only on the section in question but also on the human rights of the woman. The attached concepts of izzat and the ability of the local self appointed custodians of honour to kill is something that we need to worry about. There are cases when families have been burnt alive or killed when the next generation decided to go against convention and maybe marry outside the caste. The fact that the state does not consider the rape or assault based on caste lines to be a crime needs to be taken up at all decision making levels. The need to sensitize the police and the judiciary about violence on women has to be taken up as a priority at the level of the legislating bodies. The community that executes murders and rapes does think that they are committing a crime. They have never been censored or even penalized for their acts. The second spokesperson of the day, Beena Pallical from the Mobilization Resource Manager for the NCDHR coalition pointed out that the caste system is historically ingrained in the psyche of the country. The discrimination that comes with the practice of 'untouchability' has become an inherited identity over centuries. An individual is born into a caste and gets stigmatized accordingly. And though 'untouchability' as a practice was abolished under India’s constitution in 1950, the practice still persists. The marginalization based on reason of birth in certain caste, is as much a rural phenomenon as an urban problem. There have been times when economic empowerment has not led to a social or political mobility for the 'untouchables'. The current economic scenario maybe making more money or generating more income for the country, but it has not led to the development of the backward castes. There are 1% billionaires in the country and over 75% living below poverty line. The historic caste violence manifests itself in the form of rape (a violence that is seen as a legitimate recourse by the upper castes to subjugate the lower castes), violence inflicted on them by various state agencies like the armed forces under the AFSPA, and the humiliation at the hands of the police. The state machinery is supposed to protect the weak and not crush it further. Additionally, Dalit women face a patriarchal struggle within the Dalit movement itself. Dalit women are not treated equally within the confines of their homes and family. Another significant study highlights the fact that most of the girls trafficked for prostitution are Dalits. One of the founder members of the MKSS, Shanker Singh, talked to the gathering about the need for women to be aware of the legislation that have been framed over the years to safeguard their rights. The legislations may be limited in their scope, they still need to be enforced. It would be only when the loopholes and drawbacks of the existing legal provisions are highlighted that better and newer laws could be made. Women need to come forward and not only demand their rights, but be parts of the legislative bodies to ensure a sensitization of the state machinery. title: Press Release by NFIW
excerpt: 28/11/2013 The National Federation of Indian Women is staging a 21 day Dharna at Jantar Mantar from November 25 to December 16, 2013 with the demand for passage of the Bill seeking 33% Reservation for
content: 28/11/2013 The National Federation of Indian Women is staging a 21 day Dharna at Jantar Mantar from November 25 to December 16, 2013 with the demand for passage of the Bill seeking 33% Reservation for Women in Parliament in the Winter Session of Parliament. Members of the NFIW from 25 states are participating in the Dharna. Each day of the agitation will address various aspects of violence against women with the main theme being “Denial of Rights and Justice is Violence”. Poverty, land rights, employment, social welfare of women, food and water security, health services, education, dowry, female foeticide, domestic and sexual violence will be some of the issues discussed during the 21 days. The issue in discussion today was the denial of health services and the increasing privatization of basic services in the country and its impact on women. Annie Raja, Secretary, NFIW said that India has one of the worst health indicators for women. Almost half of Indian women are malnourished. Maternal mortality is also very high, which should be treated as a silent genocide. She also highlighted that while the country is seeing rapid construction of super speciality hospitals, the primary health centres, which are the most important link in the provision of equitable and affordable health services, are in a dismal state, with few doctors and medicines. She further emphasised that these issues need urgent voicing and action, which cannot be done unless there is an equal representation of women in the decision making bodies, including the Parliament. Jyotsna Chatterjee of the Joint Women’s Programme, who also participated in the dharna said that the problem of health services is not only at the level of policy, but also at the level of implementation of health policies as well as insufficient funds for the same. Nikhil Dey of the Mazdoor Kisan Shakti Sangathan expressed solidarity with the cause of the dharna and underlined that while the initial demand for women’s reservation is only for 33 % seats, what we really need is at least 50 % seats. He said that this demand should not be treated as ‘positive discrimination’ but as ‘positive action’ as this articulates a basic right for equality. He further said that we should use this opportunity to demand and bring equality for women not only in Parliament but also in our homes and in work. Seema from Anandi, Gujarat, stated that the condition of women in Gujarat is much worse than what is being projected by the Gujarat Government. Government data on malnourishment in children also portrays a rosier picture than what the reality is. She said that although there has been some development in the urban areas in terms of roads etc., this is practically nil at the rural level. title: Dharna Proceedings of 28th November 2013
excerpt: The theme for Day 4 of the Dharna organized by NFIW was: Healthcare and the need for representation of women in governance. The speakers who talked to the participants and supporters were included Soc
content: The theme for Day 4 of the Dharna organized by NFIW was: Healthcare and the need for representation of women in governance. The speakers who talked to the participants and supporters were included Social Activist Nikhil Dey of the MKSS (Mazdoor Kishan Shakti Sangthan), Suchna Evum Rozgar Adhikar Abhiyan and NCPRI (National Campaign for People's Right to Information). According to Nikhil Dey, the inclusion of women in governance was the need of the hour. It was a step towards empowering the women and the society. As the most affected section of society, they are major stakeholders in the development and growth of the country. Their representation in the decision making processes is as important as any other section of society. Addressing the gathering, Dr. V Mohini Giri, Former chair, National Commission for Women, emphasized on the need for gender sensitive legislation and bills to be formulated and implemented. The crimes against women need the backing of the law. Social change can be brought about with education and sensitization. Jyotsna Chatterji, the Director of the Joint Women's Programme, educated the audience on the how women's health issues need to be addressed with sensitivity by policy makers. As policies, programmes, laws and legislation generalize, they neglect the health care needs of women. The issues that need to be addressed should include the undernourishment of women and their health needs. Social and health welfare systems need a gender sensitivity. The country will lack gender sensitive laws and policies till women are on board the decision making bodies. The representative from Anandi (Area Networking and Development Initiatives) Gujarat, Ms. Seema, while giving statistics about the health of women in Gujarat talked of patriarchy and mindsets playing an important role in the deteriorating health status of women. The government is unaware and unconcerned about the health of women as they are not considered primary citizens. The deteriorating health of the women is an indicator of their marginalization and it is important that the women get representation in governance for the rot to stop. title: Statement against the current environment of dominance over working women through sexual violence
excerpt: At a time when the citizens of India are taking up the cause of violence against women in an unprecedented united manner, and the mood of the country as a whole is of anger at the suppression and disr
content: At a time when the citizens of India are taking up the cause of violence against women in an unprecedented united manner, and the mood of the country as a whole is of anger at the suppression and disrespect of women in a chauvinistic society, it is shocking that men holding the highest offices in the four pillars of democracy in the country have been found to perpetrate the demeaning and violent acts of sexual harassment against women. It is a matter of great concern that cases are coming to light even now where Supreme Court judges, police officers, prominent media personnel and politicians have been guilty of rape and sexual harassment in its many forms. It is a symptom of the patriarchal system that exists in our society and the complete impunity with which the perpetrators get away with their crimes. It is the duty of those in positions of responsibility, and of those who are in the public eye, to act with the highest moral standards and ethics. The youth of the nation look towards these individuals as role models. Such perpetrators cannot be above the law but must be seen by the public to go through the same process of investigation and punishment that must follow such a complaint. At a time when women are rising in their professions and gaining top positions in their fields, both nationally and globally, it is this insecurity felt by men in power that seeks to crush the spirit of women by domination through sexual violence and with threats of dire consequences if the offence is reported. It is shameful that we still have to fight for a safe working environment for women, and for the surety of punishment and redressal, despite all the laws that have been enacted. It is the non-implementation of these laws, the complicity of the keepers of the law, the gender unequal treatment at home and at the workplace that perpetuate the constant discrimination against women despite the clear Constitutional provision of the equal status of women. NFIW strongly condemns the actions of Tarun Tejpal, founder editor of the investigative news magazine Tehelka, a man whose writings have always revolved around the moral and ethical aspects of the news items published in his magazine. The sense of disappointment and the feeling of being let down is all the more intense because of what he and his magazine sought to represent to the people. NFIW also condemns the trivialization of the horrific incident by the management of Tehelka by treating it as an “internal matter” and “an untoward incident” and believing that a mere apology and casual self assigned farcical punishment would substitute for due process of law. This case also brings out the concern that there is no Sexual Harassment Committee set up in many public offices, despite The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013 having come into force in April this year, making such a committee mandatory in all government and private companies. The other alarming case is of the recent reports of Narendra Modi, Chief Minister of Gujarat and contender for the position of the Prime Minister of India in the coming Lok Sabha elections, Amit Shah, the then Home Minister of Gujarat and GL Singhal, Superintendent of the Gujarat Anti Terrorist Squad, misusing Government machinery and funds to stalk a young woman architect and put her under continuous surveillance for entirely personal reasons. None of them have denied these charges as of now. The questions that arise – is ours really a free, democratic governance? Where is the respect for personal privacy and rights? At the very least, do Modi and Shah not fall under the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, for stalking? It gets worse. A Judge of the Supreme Court of India, the apex court of the country, has been charged with sexual harassment by a woman intern. She has also formally brought to light that hers was not an isolated case and that women are subjected to such humiliating experiences regularly in the judiciary. Unless these cases are taken up by our law enforcing agencies in a transparent and unbiased manner and unless due punishment is meted out to the perpetrators, the people of this country will lose faith in the credibility of these apex institutions, the pillars of our democracy. We urge all women to be strong and make full use of the provisions in the laws so that these act as real deterrents for the perpetration of crimes against women. We reiterate our demand that the laws of our country be fully implemented in letter and spirit. content: The National Federation of Indian Women is staging a 21 day Dharna, at Jantar Mantar from November 25 to December 16, 2013 with the demand for passage of the ‘Bill seeking 33% Reservation for Women in Parliament’, to be passed in the Winter Session of Parliament. The inaugural day coincided with the International Day for Violence Against Women. Each day of the agitation will address the various aspects of violence against women with the main theme being “Denial of Rights and Justice is Violence”. Poverty, land rights, employment, social welfare of women, food and water security, health services, education, dowry, female foeticide, domestic and sexual violence will be some of the issues discussed during the 21 days. Members of the NFIW from 25 states are participating in the Dharna. Despite several women friendly laws that exist, very few have been implemented. Enacting some of these laws have taken several years. The Sexual Harassment at Workplace (Prevention and Redressal) Act, has taken over 15 years to be enacted. The Supreme Court itself has only now constituted the committee against sexual harassment after a young lawyer went public with her harrowing experience. All this makes it imperative for women to be part of the decision making processes and bodies, particularly in the Parliament and Legislative Assemblies to ensure a just and equitable society. The issues taken up today were sexual harassment, right to work and social security. Dr. BV Vijayalakshmi, President of the All India Anganwadi Workers Federation and lifelong Trade Unionist, Anuradha Talwar of NTUI, Nikhil Dey of MKSS and NCPRI, Ms Rajni Tilak Dalit human rights activist, writer and feminist, expressed solidarity and addressed the participants. NFIW members from different states also spoke of their experiences and why they wanted representation in the decision making bodies. NFIW released a statement against the current environment of dominance over working women through sexual violence that is enclosed with this press release. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-6939125b94884', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: Press Release 26th November 2013
excerpt: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) With crimes against women escalating to an unacceptable level and all organs of government finding it near impossible to curb this trend, leading women’s gro
content: NATIONAL FEDERATION OF INDIAN WOMEN (NFIW) With crimes against women escalating to an unacceptable level and all organs of government finding it near impossible to curb this trend, leading women’s group, NFIW has launched a 21 day dharna from 25 November to 16 December, 2013 to drive home the point that any further delay of the passage of the 33% Women’s Reservation Bill is going to cost all parties that are in election mode at the state and national level dearly. Speaking about the dharna, Ms. Annie Raja, General Secretary, NFIW emphasized that women leaders from as many as 25 states are determined to make this a major electoral issue in 2014. “We want the Prime Minister to show that his concern for women is not just in thought but in deed and nothing could demonstrate this better by ensuring the passage of the women’s reservation bill in the last Parliamentary session” she added. Since each day of the agitation aims to address various aspects of violence against women, the issue in discussion today was on structural violence, specifically land rights, employment, food and water security. The dharna saw participation of women from Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Kerala, Karnataka, Bengal and Delhi, who talked about the respective scenario of women’s right to land, work and essential services in their states. Introducing this issue, Annie Raja, stated that the issue of women’s rights to land is essentially linked to the question of reservation, because while a majority of women in this country are engaged in agriculture, but they own less than 4 per cent of land holdings. This issue also does not find much discussion in the Parliament, as there are so few women representatives to speak on the same. Framing the issue of land, economist Jaya Mehta underlined that almost 42 per cent of farmers in the country do not own land, and among the 58 per cent who do, 66 per cent own very small land holdings, which is inadequate for their sustenance and many times forces them to sell their land. the marginal land holdings in the fact that almost 70 per cent of people in this country go hungry every day. Among those who own land, women have a very marginal share, even though they work very hard on the farms as laborers or helpers. While the new land act talks of forcible land acquisition, it does not address the issue of small and marginal farmers. Among them, women have even less share of land rights. she also gave the example of collective farming Kudumsri in Kerala where women have being formed collectives to farm hectares of fallow land. Addressed the dharna, Achuthan, Rajya Sabha M.P. that NFIW has a special place among women’s organizations not only because of its instrumental role in pushing 33 per cent reservation for women in Rajya Sabha, but also because it is one of the strongest voices against violence on women. He also said that the struggle for women’s reservations in Lok Sabha is hard as there are powerful anti women forces in the Parliament, who despite their stated commitment to the cause are bent on blocking its passage. Others who expressed solidarity were Harsh Mander, a former NAC member and social activists such as Kavita Srivastva, Deepa Sinha and Sejal Anand. content: Nirbhaya did not survive the brutality, Mathura did. This case highlights the milestones we have crossed in trying to get justice for rape victims, and how many more miles we have to go. The two finger test and previous sexual history are no longer licenses for rapists to be pardoned. The new rape laws and judgements and the hype make it seem as if we have managed to secure justice for all women in the country. Yet every day we see a Mathura who knows that justice is not for her coz she is poor, or rural or has suffered custodial rape, or some reason that defies sensibilities. We wait for higher courts to reverse rulings and we wait for justifications for the rapists. We look for factors from poverty to mindset that provoked the rapists to rape or the factors that convinced the judges that the criminals were justified. title: Concept Note
excerpt: Joint Action on 33 % Women Reservation Bill According to the Human Development Report 2013[1], India ranks 132 out of 148 countries on the Gender Inequality Index. Only 10.9 per cent of the parliament
content: Joint Action on 33 % Women Reservation Bill According to the Human Development Report 2013[1], India ranks 132 out of 148 countries on the Gender Inequality Index. Only 10.9 per cent of the parliamentary seats are held by women, and 26.6 per cent of adult women have reached a secondary or higher level of education, compared with 50.4 per cent of their male counterparts. For every 100,000 live births, 200 women die of causes related to pregnancy, and female participation in the labour market is 29 per cent, compared with 80.7 per cent for men. Women’s ownership to land and property is less than 4 %, whereas 73 % of food is produced by rural women (NSS 66th-2009-10). According to the National Crime Record Bureau Statistics, there has been a nationwide hike of 7.1% in crimes against women since 2010. Therefore, ground zero evidences of inequality, sex based discrimination have also been indicated in various studies that women & girls are still distanced by democratic institutions, legal & administrative mechanisms. Thus, the inaccessibility & inability to own land & property, livelihoods, accesses to health and education and lack of political participation, are seen to be common feature in the globalized India. These development indicators are restricting women from exercising political rights also. However these development indicators also intimately related to women’s poverty and exclusion. The above development exclusion have further manifested in violation women human rights through numerous ways and varies in prevalence and forms based on numerous factors including geographic location. Some manifestations include: sexual violence, domestic violence, caste-based discrimination and violence, dowry related deaths, crimes in the name of honour, witch-hunting, sati, violence against lesbian, bisexual, and transgender people, forced and/or early marriages, deprivation of access to water and basic sanitation, violence against women with disabilities, sexual and reproductive rights violations, sex selection practices, violence in custodial settings and violence in conflict situations, among others. The patriarchal norms, feudal stereotypes, social and gender prejudices, customary practises including market economy framework, all restrict marginalised and women from livelihood and owning land productive resources. This resulting in the Dalits, women, youth & including children are victims of multiple layers of discrimination along with multiple challenges of—forced migration leading to trafficking & bonded labour. Mechanisms and instruments: India has ratified several international human rights treaties—ICESCR, CERD, CEDAW and has very clear and binding international obligations under these with respect to equality and non-discrimination and also has a number of laws in place domestically, which address many of these issues. But despite various domestic laws, affirmative schemes and programmes in place, rights of many women in India continue to be violated, with impunity as the norm. This can be attributed mainly to the patriarchal nature of Indian society that not only perpetuates gender inequality but also prevents implementation of policies and programmes in an equitable way. Multiple and intersecting factors contribute to gender discrimination and violence against women. Therefore it requires to address the causes of gender based exclusion, inequality, violence and discrimination at institutional, structural, ideological and operational levels this will be possible only by women’s equal participation in decision making processes at all levels of—Legislative, Judiciary and Executive. At the institutional level— ensure the implementation of policies that empower women, e.g. concerning inheritance and property rights, access to justice, access to credit, fair choice of work, equal treatment at work, safe working conditions, equal pay, improved response to violence against women, enforcement, educational, health, and other service-related policies and actions. It is time to shift in attitudes and social conditioning through State power three arenas—economics, politics and the law, it is possible only through women equal representation in the parliament and legislative council. Unless this recognised achieving gender equality and women human rights will continue to remain distance hope/elusive. _________________________________________________________________________ Violence at the family level – such as domestic violence, forced prostitution by the family; violence against domestic workers and the girl-child (non-spousal violence, violence related to exploitation); sex-selective abortion and infanticide; dowry deaths, honour killing; harmful cultural practices such as early or forced marriages; health and nutrition differentials; literacy levels; religious/customary laws which discriminate against women. Violence at the community/market level – such as rape/sexual assault; honour killing; sexual harassment; violence within institutions; trafficking and forced prostitution; violence against women migrant workers; pornography; discrimination in employment choices and conditions; wage differentials and ownership of land and property. Violence perpetrated or condoned by the State – such as gender-based violence during armed conflict; custodial violence; discriminatory laws on family/succession, divorce rights; violence against refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs); and violence against women from indigenous and minority groups. __ATA = window.__ATA || {}; __ATA.cmd = window.__ATA.cmd || []; __ATA.cmd.push(function() { __ATA.initVideoSlot('atatags-370373-693912680e415', { sectionId: '370373', format: 'inread' }); });

title: INVITE: Joint Action on 33 % Women Reservation Bill
excerpt: In 1996, the 81st Constitutional Amendment Bill was proposed in Parliament for women reservation in Parliament and State Legislative Assemblies to ensure participatory Democracy and thereby political
content: In 1996, the 81st Constitutional Amendment Bill was proposed in Parliament for women reservation in Parliament and State Legislative Assemblies to ensure participatory Democracy and thereby political empowerment of women.. To resolve the matter, a joint Parliamentary Committee was formed under the Chairpersonship of Smt. Gita Mukherjee The passage of the 33% women’s Reservation Bill in the Rajya Sabha on 9th March 2010, brought a sense of optimism in the women of this country about its being passed by the Lok Sabha and becoming a law. Unfortunately, after more than 3 years also this Bill still awaits its passage in the Lok Sabha. This has brought a sense of disappointment among women’s organizations and to all those committed for political empowerment of women. The participation of women in the panchayats with 33% and even 50% reservation is bringing a change in the thought process at the local level. It has brought lakhs of women in the political arena and slowly they are able to mark their presence. Together, we have all struggled for this right of women. The time has come to carry forward our relentless struggle especially in these difficult times when vested interests are trying to sabotage the passage of this Bill. Now NFIW is organising a 21 day Joint Action programme in front of Parliament at Jantar Mantar from 25 November 2013, the International Day of Violence against women, to 16 December 2013, the first anniversary of the gruesome assault on Nirbhaya in Delhi. It is a National Dharna to demand the passage of the 33% Women’s Reservation Bill in the coming winter session of Parliament. We all have been together in these struggles and hope to get continued support on this issue and in the programme. This Dharna intends to highlight the growing violence and crime against women at all levels, be it structural violence like poverty and inequality, invisible violence such as violation of human rights, denial of health and education and visible violence like sexual assaults and increasing crime against women. We firmly believe that women’s equal participation in decision-making processes will ensure implementation of policies and schemes that empower women. Unless women get at least 1/3rd representation in parliament and legislative assemblies, achieving gender equality and human rights of women will remain a distant dream. We expect your wholehearted support to this cause. Please participate in this Dharna and express your solidarity with this joint movement.
